Text: CONVERSION OF OVERSEAS

Speaker: NA
Text: INDEBTEDNESS.

Speaker: Mr SCULLIN
Text: I ask the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister whether there is any authority

Speaker: NA
Text: for the cable message published in

Speaker: NA
Text: morning's newspaper that the GovernSouth

Speaker: NA
Text: ment does not intend to convert at an

Speaker: NA
Text: early date Australian loans bearing

Speaker: NA
Text: interest at more than S per cent., other

Speaker: NA
Text: than tbe New South Wales loan,

Speaker: NA
Text: £13,000,000 which will fall due on. the

Speaker: NA
Text: 1st November?

Speaker: Mr LYONS
Text: Ther e is n« authority

Speaker: NA
Text: for the published statement. The

Speaker: NA
Text: immediate necessity before the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: meut is the conversion of the New South

Speaker: NA
Text: AVales loan which will mature on the

Speaker: NA
Text: 1st November, but the conversion of

Speaker: NA
Text: other overseas indebtedness is under the

Speaker: NA
Text: constant consideration of the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. Only by putting our house in

Speaker: NA
Text: order and maintaining our credit abroad

Speaker: NA
Text: can we hope for any improvement in the

Speaker: NA
Text: rate of interest on the overseas debt. We

Speaker: NA
Text: must be ready to convert the balance of

Speaker: NA
Text: the debt when the opportunity offers.

Speaker: Mr LANE

Text: obstacles to dealing with communist

Text: T h e r e is no legal

Speaker: NA
Text: vision by which the Government or the

Text: Although the Postinuster-General would not

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: -Order ! I cannot..allow tbe question of

Text: the honorable member. He has been in

Text: importance.

Text: I cannot allow the

Speaker: NA
Text: COAL DISPUTE.

Speaker: Mr JAMES
Text: I s it not a fact that the

Speaker: NA
Text: primary cause of the threatened trouble

Speaker: NA
Text: Serin the coal industry throughout Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia is the interference of a State tri-

Speaker: NA
Text: the bunal in Victoria which has given an

Speaker: NA
Text: award reducing the wages of the workers

Speaker: NA
Text: a further 20 per cent, on top of the 12-J

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent, reduction that was made dur-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the lockout in 1929 and 1930? Sec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion 28 of the Industrial Peace Act

Speaker: NA
Text: reads-

Speaker: NA
Text: No award or order of a special tribunal or

Speaker: NA
Text: local board shall be challenged, appealed

Speaker: NA
Text: against, reviewed, quashed or called in ques-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, or be subject to prohibition, mandamus,

Speaker: NA
Text: or injunction in any court on any account

Speaker: NA
Text: whatever.

Speaker: NA
Text: I n view of the fact that the coal-mining

Speaker: NA
Text: industry is governed by an award of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Coal Tribunal set up under this act, the

Speaker: NA
Text: provisions of which have been over-

Speaker: NA
Text: ridden by a State tribunal, does the

Speaker: NA
Text: Attorney-General intend to take 'appro-

Speaker: NA
Text: priate action against the State Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment ? I f not, will he endeavour to avoid

Speaker: NA
Text: the threatened dispute by calling a com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pulsory conference of the parties con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cerned as provided for in the act?

Speaker: Mr LATHAM
Text: A s at present ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: vised, I do not anticipate that there will

Speaker: NA
Text: be any general stoppage in the coal-

Speaker: NA
Text: mining industry of Australia. The

Speaker: NA
Text: award of the Victorian State tribunal

Speaker: NA
Text: was made, I understand, pursuant to the

Speaker: NA
Text: provisions of an act recently passed by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Victorian Parliament after the

Speaker: NA
Text: federal award applicable to Wonthaggi

Speaker: NA
Text: had been set aside by the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: Arbitration Court. The act passed by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Victorian Parliament was supported

Speaker: NA
Text: by the honorable member for Wonthaggi

Speaker: NA
Text: in that Parliament. I t has never been

Speaker: NA
Text: suggested, so far as I am aware, except

Speaker: NA
Text: by the honorable member for Hunter

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr James), that any award made

Speaker: NA
Text: under the Industrial Peace Act is

Speaker: NA
Text: in any way inconsistent with the

Speaker: NA
Text: Victorian award. I f there ever were

Speaker: NA
Text: such an award it would almost certainly

Speaker: NA
Text: have expired, for no award has been made

Speaker: NA
Text: under the Industrial Peace Act since

Speaker: NA
Text: July; 1928. I f there were such an award

Speaker: NA
Text: in force the matter would be one for de-

Speaker: NA
Text: cision by the appropriate tribunal, and

Speaker: NA
Text: not for a Minister of the Crown.

Text: NEOPHONE TELEPHONE.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr B. GEEEN asked the Postmaster-

Speaker: NA
Text: General, upon notice-

Speaker: NA
Text: 1. Does he concede the accuracy of the state-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment published in the Sydney Morning Herald

Speaker: NA
Text: of the 2nd instant, that the advent of the new

Speaker: NA
Text: " Neophone " telephone has immediately demon-

Speaker: NA
Text: strated to Australian users how much their

Speaker: NA
Text: telephone service^ is behind that of Britain

Speaker: NA
Text: and America?

Speaker: NA
Text: 2. Is i t a fact, as stated by the President

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Electrical Association of New South

Speaker: NA
Text: Wales, that i t is only necessary to whisper

Speaker: NA
Text: . . 2,103 into the instrument, and tho reception at'the

Speaker: NA
Text: other end is well modulated, clear and dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: 3. W i l l lie reconsider the decision of his

Speaker: NA
Text: department to give only permissive right to

Speaker: NA
Text: telephone subscribers to install the "Neophone"

Speaker: NA
Text: (after purchasing i t themselves) and to insist

Speaker: NA
Text: upon the department's right to take over all

Speaker: NA
Text: Each, the instruments so installed at any later date

Speaker: NA
Text: f *. d. at the department's valuation?

Speaker: NA
Text: 1 12 3 4. I f at any future time i t should be deemed

Speaker: NA
Text: npcfssary by tlie department to install a dif-

Speaker: NA
Text: ferent type of instrument, w i l l the department

Speaker: NA
Text: agree to a subscriber retaining possession of

Speaker: NA
Text: the " Neophone " after its disconnexion, rather

Speaker: NA
Text: than surrendering i t to the department?

Speaker: NA
Text: 5. Is i t a fact that the President of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Electrical Association of New South Wales

Speaker: NA
Text: stated that there are several firms i n Sydney

Speaker: NA
Text: capable of manufacturing the new telephone at

Speaker: NA
Text: a reasonable price, and that -the only difficulty

Speaker: NA
Text: is in securing an order from the post office

Speaker: NA
Text: large enough to jus tify the initia l installation

Speaker: NA
Text: of the necessary machinery?

Speaker: NA
Text: 6. Has his attention been drawn to the fol-

Speaker: NA
Text: lowing statement of the President of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Electrical Association of New South Wales:-

Speaker: NA
Text: " I t is unfortunate that there should be a large

Speaker: NA
Text: number of the old telephone receivers i n stock,

Speaker: NA
Text: but if the post office had followed the usual

Speaker: NA
Text: commercial routine, the major portion of the

Speaker: NA
Text: capital cost of those instruments would have

Speaker: NA
Text: been written off within five-years from their

Speaker: NA
Text: initial installation . . . i t seems scarcely

Speaker: NA
Text: fair for the Post Office Department to put

Speaker: NA
Text: difficulties in the way of its introduction until

Speaker: NA
Text: the old instruments have all been re-

Speaker: NA
Text: installed"?

Speaker: NA
Text: 7. I f so, what action does he propose taking

Speaker: NA
Text: in regard to the whole question?

Speaker: Mr FENTON
Text: Th e answers to the

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member's questions are as fol-

Speaker: NA
Text: low :-

Speaker: NA
Text: 1. The "Neophone" is. not available i n the

Speaker: NA
Text: American telephone service. I t is a develop-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of the British Post Office and Messrs.

Speaker: NA
Text: Siemens Brothers. Its advent does not demon-

Speaker: NA
Text: strate that the Australian telephone service

Speaker: NA
Text: is behind that of other countries.

Speaker: NA
Text: 2. The statement could hardly be accepted

Speaker: NA
Text: as ono of scientific accuracy, but the transmis-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion qualities of the instrument are good and

Speaker: NA
Text: slightly better than the instruments which

Speaker: NA
Text: have hitherto been standard in telephone

Speaker: NA
Text: administrations. I t w i l l be recognized that the

Speaker: NA
Text: telephone instrument is not the only item

Speaker: NA
Text: affecting the transmission of clear speech.

Speaker: NA
Text: The satisfactory transmission of speech over

Speaker: NA
Text: very long distances in Australia compares most

Speaker: NA
Text: favorably with what has been accomplished

Speaker: NA
Text: elsewhere. This high quality of service is

Speaker: NA
Text: regularly being rendered on instruments which

Speaker: NA
Text: are not of the "Neophone" type.

Speaker: NA
Text: 3. The department's permission is of a ten-

Speaker: NA
Text: tative character, and may be withdrawn when-

Speaker: NA
Text: ever that step appears to be desirable. The

Speaker: NA
Text: department may or may not wish to take over

Speaker: NA
Text: instruments which have been purchased pri-

Speaker: NA
Text: vately. That question will be better left for

Speaker: NA
Text: negotiation and determination when the time

Speaker: NA
Text: arrives.

Speaker: NA
Text: 4. I f the instrument is the property of the

Speaker: NA
Text: subscriber and is removed from the telephone

Speaker: NA
Text: service the department would have no wish

Speaker: NA
Text: to acquire i t .

Speaker: NA
Text: 5. Such a statement has been noticed i n the

Speaker: NA
Text: press.

Speaker: NA
Text: 6. Yes; but to write off the cost of a tele-

Speaker: NA
Text: phone in five years would impose a heavy

Speaker: NA
Text: burden on telephone subscribers, for i t would

Speaker: NA
Text: cause an altogether unnecessary inflation of

Speaker: NA
Text: telephone tariffs. Tlie department's attitude

Speaker: NA
Text: will be governed entirely by what i t believes

Speaker: NA
Text: to be in the best interests of telephone sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: scribers as a body, and the question of

Speaker: NA
Text: economics is obviously an important factor.

Speaker: NA
Text: The department has already shown that i t does

Speaker: NA
Text: not wish to arrest progress, even in the direc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of withholding permission for the instal-

Speaker: NA
Text: lation of an instrument which, in certain cir-

Speaker: NA
Text: cumstances, may be more conveniently used.

Speaker: NA
Text: Naturally, however, those who wish to acquire

Speaker: NA
Text: a more modern instrument must expect to

Speaker: NA
Text: contribute to the enhanced cost, for i t would

Speaker: NA
Text: be unreasonable that the increased charges

Speaker: NA
Text: should be passed on to the very large number

Speaker: NA
Text: of users who w i l l not find i t essential to make

Speaker: NA
Text: such a change.

Speaker: NA
Text: 7. See reply to 6.

Text: (a) Three thousand four hundred and

Speaker: NA
Text: ninetv-thrce.

Speaker: NA
Text: (c) and (rf) The reply furnished by the

Speaker: NA
Text: HIGH COMMISSIONEE BIL L.

Speaker: NA
Text: SECOND BEADING.

Speaker: Mr LYONS
Text: Wilmot-Prim e Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: of sala- and Treasurer) [3.32] - I move-

Speaker: NA
Text: That the bill be now read a second time. '

Speaker: NA
Text: This measure amends the High Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: missioner Act 1909 by adding to i l

Speaker: NA
Text: a section enabling a Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister, in certain circumstances, to

Speaker: NA
Text: exercise the powers and to perform the

Speaker: NA
Text: of sala- duties now vested in the High Commis-

Speaker: NA
Text: sioner. I t is not the intention of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government to fill at present

Speaker: NA
Text: vacancy brought about by

Speaker: NA
Text: the retirement of Sir . Granville

Speaker: NA
Text: Ryrie. The Minister without Portfolio

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Bruce) arrived in London prac-

Speaker: NA
Text: tically simultaneously with the ending

Speaker: NA
Text: of Sir Granville Byrie's term of office,

Speaker: NA
Text: and it is intended that the right honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: gentleman shall remain in London for

Speaker: NA
Text: endowsome time as Besident Minister. I n that

Speaker: NA
Text: child capacity he will carry out most important

Speaker: NA
Text: work concerning Australianfinance.

Speaker: NA
Text: His first task will be to make arrange-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments for the conversion of the New

Speaker: NA
Text: paid South Wales loan which falls due in

Speaker: NA
Text: with November. I n addition he will perform

Speaker: NA
Text: of the duties ordinarily carried out by-the

Speaker: NA
Text: High Commissioner. Apart from the

Speaker: NA
Text: advantages expected from this arrange-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, certain economies will be effected.

Speaker: NA
Text: I t is intended that the operation of

Speaker: NA
Text: the proposed new section shall be limited

Speaker: NA
Text: to two years. No term has been set to

Speaker: NA
Text: the appointment of Mr Bruce as Besident

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister in London. The right honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able gentleman will remain in the English

Speaker: NA
Text: PAPEES. capital so long as is deemed necessary to

Speaker: NA
Text: keep him there to carry out the important

Speaker: NA
Text: tasks to which I have referred. I f the

Speaker: NA
Text: arrangement is discontinued at any time

Speaker: NA
Text: during the next two years, the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment will probably appoint a High

Speaker: NA
Text: Commissioner. The provisions of this

Speaker: NA
Text: bill will apply only while the position

Speaker: NA
Text: held, by a Commonwealth Minister.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ii' experience should demonstrate that it

Speaker: NA
Text: would be wise to continue, after Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bruce returns, to have a .Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister resident in London

Speaker: Mr MAKIN
Text: Perhap s the present

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister himself.

Speaker: Mr LYONS
Text: Th e houorable gentle-

Speaker: NA
Text: man may rest assured that there is no

Speaker: NA
Text: possibility of that happening. Should

Speaker: NA
Text: experience prove that the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: would benefit by having a Resident

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister in London to perform these

Speaker: NA
Text: duties i t ' will be necessary, after two

Speaker: NA
Text: years, again to amend the High Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: missioner Act.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Bruce being now in London, and

Speaker: NA
Text: about to take up the duties of the office,

Speaker: NA
Text: it. is necessary to pass the bill without

Speaker: NA
Text: delay. I hope that honorable members

Speaker: NA
Text: will realize the desirability of having

Speaker: NA
Text: in London at the present time a Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: knowing the political and financial

Speaker: NA
Text: circumstances of Australia, and able to

Speaker: NA
Text: carry out the important and delicate

Speaker: NA
Text: duties which have to be undertaken. I t

Speaker: NA
Text: will be agreed that Mr Bruce is at least

Speaker: NA
Text: as well qualified to perform the work of

Speaker: NA
Text: the High Commissioner's office as any

Speaker: NA
Text: gentleman who has preceded him as High

Speaker: NA
Text: Commissioner, and I am confident that

Speaker: NA
Text: the right honorable gentleman will render

Speaker: NA
Text: real service to Australia while represent-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the Commonwealth in London.

Speaker: Mr SCULLIN
Text: Yarra) [3.39] -The

Speaker: NA
Text: bill is a much more important measure

Speaker: NA
Text: than it, may at first appear,

Speaker: NA
Text: although it contains practically

Speaker: NA
Text: isiily one clause, adding

Speaker: NA
Text: new section to the High Commissioner

Speaker: NA
Text: Act 1909. I f it merely provided for a

Speaker: NA
Text: temporary arrangement under which a

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister visiting London on a special

Speaker: NA
Text: mission would be empowered to carry out

Speaker: NA
Text: the duties of High Commissioner, there

Speaker: NA
Text: could be no real objection to tbe measure,

Speaker: NA
Text: and in suah circumstances I would not

Speaker: NA
Text: offer any. But it involves more than

Speaker: NA
Text: that. An announcement was made some

Speaker: NA
Text: time ago by the Prime Minister on behalf

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Government that, in effect, a new

Speaker: NA
Text: policy was to be adopted; that we were

Speaker: NA
Text: to be governed partly from London; that

Speaker: NA
Text: we were to have a Besident Minister in

Speaker: NA
Text: .London; and that he would be the Bight

Speaker: NA
Text: Honorable S. M. Bruce.

Speaker: NA
Text: When this bill is passed, it will give-

Speaker: NA
Text: the authority of this Parliament to the-

Speaker: NA
Text: principle of appointing a Besident Min-

Speaker: NA
Text: ister abroad. That being so, one would,

Speaker: NA
Text: have expected the head of the Go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment, when introducing this startling;

Speaker: NA
Text: innovation so far as Australian politics

Speaker: NA
Text: are concerned, to put forward sound

Speaker: NA
Text: reasons to justify it. The Prime-

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister said, in the first place, that

Speaker: NA
Text: there was some important work to bet

Speaker: NA
Text: done in London by the Minister whom it-

Speaker: NA
Text: is proposed to appoint. I believe that

Speaker: NA
Text: there is important work to be done in.

Speaker: NA
Text: London. I take no objection to the

Speaker: NA
Text: presence in London of a Minister at the

Speaker: NA
Text: present time, and so long as important-

Speaker: NA
Text: duties remain to be done, such as the

Speaker: NA
Text: conversion of loans, I approve of a Min-

Speaker: NA
Text: ister from Australia being present in

Speaker: NA
Text: London. But is it contemplated that this

Speaker: NA
Text: work will take two years, or even one

Speaker: NA
Text: year to accomplish? The conversion of

Speaker: NA
Text: our loans overseas to a lower rate of in-

Speaker: NA
Text: terest is urgent. The Prime Minister,,

Speaker: NA
Text: when sitting in opposition, once declared

Speaker: NA
Text: publicly that, were he in power, his first

Speaker: NA
Text: act would be to go to London and arrange

Speaker: NA
Text: for the conversion of our overseas in-

Speaker: NA
Text: debtedness at a lower rate of interest;

Speaker: NA
Text: then he would come back to Australia and

Speaker: NA
Text: arrange the conversion of the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: debt. I n my opinion, he was putting the

Speaker: NA
Text: cart before the horse, but, at any rate,

Speaker: NA
Text: so urgent did he believe the conversion of

Speaker: NA
Text: our overseas indebtedness to be, that he

Speaker: NA
Text: would have undertaken the task im-

Speaker: NA
Text: mediately. My government believed that

Speaker: NA
Text: the first duty v/as to convert the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian debt so as to give a lead to over-

Speaker: NA
Text: a seas bondholders; then we could approach

Speaker: NA
Text: the overseas bondholders, telling them

Speaker: NA
Text: that we had put our own house in order,

Speaker: NA
Text: and asking them to meet us. A con-

Speaker: NA
Text: siderable time has elapsed since the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister assumed office, but

Speaker: NA
Text: nothing has been done to arrange for the

Speaker: NA
Text: conversion of our overseas indebtedness.

Speaker: NA
Text: I do not propose to offer any criticism

Speaker: NA
Text: at this juncture which might hamper the

Speaker: NA
Text: activities of the right honorable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Flinders ( Mr Bruce) while he is in

Speaker: NA
Text: London on a delicate mission. Indeed,

Speaker: NA
Text: anything I can do to help him I will

Speaker: NA
Text: gladly do, because it is essential to Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia that interest rates be reduced to

Speaker: NA
Text: something corresponding to the price

Speaker: NA
Text: levels prevailing when the debts were

Speaker: NA
Text: contracted. That, however, does not

Speaker: NA
Text: justify a proposal for keeping a per-

Speaker: NA
Text: manent or Resident Minister in London.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is no doubt that this appointment

Speaker: NA
Text: marks the beginning of a new policy. I f

Speaker: NA
Text: this Government is in office when the

Speaker: NA
Text: period provided in the bill expires, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister will be able to find the

Speaker: NA
Text: Same excuses for keeping the Resident

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister in London for a further term

Speaker: NA
Text: that he has now put forward for his

Speaker: NA
Text: appointment. The presence of a Min-

Speaker: NA
Text: ister in London at the present time to

Speaker: NA
Text: consult with financial institutions, with

Speaker: NA
Text: the heads of the Government, and with

Speaker: NA
Text: subscribers to Australian: loans, is very

Speaker: NA
Text: important, nordo I believe bhat this

Speaker: NA
Text: work could be done so effectively by

Speaker: NA
Text: an officer, however capable, as by

Speaker: NA
Text: a Minister. I maintain, however, that,

Speaker: NA
Text: once the negotiations have been completed,

Speaker: NA
Text: and the contacts established by a respon-

Speaker: NA
Text: sible Minister, the officer we now have in

Speaker: NA
Text: London as financial adviser could carry

Speaker: NA
Text: out the detailed work quite as capably as

Speaker: NA
Text: any Minister. I shall go further, and say

Speaker: NA
Text: that Mr Collins, with the experience he

Speaker: NA
Text: had in the Treasury in Australia, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: further experience he has had in London,

Speaker: NA
Text: would probably be able to carry out the

Speaker: NA
Text: detailed negotiations even better than

Speaker: NA
Text: could the Minister.

Speaker: NA
Text: What need is there to give power to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Resident Minister to administer Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia 1

Speaker: NA
Text: House? That institution

Speaker: NA
Text: is now being administered

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Collins, who has ^really done the

Speaker: NA
Text: work for over a year. The High Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: missioner is the representative of the

Speaker: NA
Text: nation, and i f the nation can afford so

Speaker: NA
Text: costly a representative at the present time

Speaker: NA
Text: to maintain our prestige, well and good.

Speaker: NA
Text: In these times, however, I do not think

Speaker: NA
Text: that Australia can afford to maintain such

Speaker: NA
Text: a position, and it is my opinion that, when

Speaker: NA
Text: the present term expires we should

Speaker: NA
Text: do in the case 'of the High Commissioner-

Speaker: NA
Text: ship what we have done in the case of the

Speaker: NA
Text: office of the Australian Commissioner-

Speaker: NA
Text: General in the United States of America.

Speaker: Mr WHITE
Text: Th e Trade Commissioner

Speaker: NA
Text: acted on his own initiative.

Speaker: Mr SCULLIN
Text: Th e honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber for Balaclava does not know every-

Speaker: NA
Text: thing about these matters, although he

Speaker: NA
Text: thinks that he does. I offer no criticism

Speaker: NA
Text: of our erstwhile representative in the

Speaker: NA
Text: United States of America. That gentle-

Speaker: NA
Text: man knew the opinion, of the Government,

Speaker: NA
Text: and he tendered his resignation to me in

Speaker: NA
Text: a proper public 3pirit. I accepted the

Speaker: NA
Text: resignation in the same spirit.. The posi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion in the United States of America be-

Speaker: NA
Text: came vacant by the resignation of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commissioner-General, and we did not fill

Speaker: NA
Text: it, but we allowed the permanent secretary

Speaker: NA
Text: to carry on, with the result that nothing

Speaker: NA
Text: has been lost, and no interests have been

Speaker: NA
Text: injured. I say deliberately, and by virtue

Speaker: NA
Text: of the inside knowledge I possess, that

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia would be just as capably repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sented at Australia House for the next

Speaker: NA
Text: twelve months or two years i f we allowed

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Collins to carry on, as i t has been dur-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the last two years. Honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers have to determine whether there is

Speaker: NA
Text: any justification for our representation

Speaker: NA
Text: abroad on an elaborate scale, when we are

Speaker: NA
Text: forced at home to out and slash our

Speaker: NA
Text: expenditure inorder to: meet our obliga-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Prime Minister,, when, introducing

Speaker: NA
Text: this measure,, made only one reference to

Speaker: NA
Text: costs. He said that a saving would be

Speaker: NA
Text: effected by adopting the new proposal,

Speaker: NA
Text: but he gave no details. I have seen press

Speaker: NA
Text: statements to the effect that Mr Bruce

Speaker: NA
Text: will receive the same salary a3 would be

Speaker: NA
Text: paid to a High Commissioner. I do not

Speaker: NA
Text: know whether there was any authority

Speaker: NA
Text: for those statements.

Speaker: Mr LYONS
Text: The y are correct.

Speaker: Mr SCULLIN
Text: Tha t is the first inti-

Speaker: NA
Text: mation this House has had of the matter.

Speaker: Mr LATHAM
Text: Th e expenditure is pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vided for in the Estimates. Mr Bruce

Speaker: NA
Text: will receive the salary he would have

Speaker: NA
Text: received had he remained here, and an

Speaker: NA
Text: allowance to make up his salary to what

Speaker: NA
Text: the High Commissioner has been receiv-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing. There will be a saving, therefore,

Speaker: NA
Text: of the amount he would have received had

Speaker: NA
Text: he remained here.

Speaker: Mr SCULLIN
Text: -I take it, then, that

Speaker: NA
Text: the amount of the saving will be deducted

Speaker: NA
Text: from the lump sum voted for ministerial

Speaker: NA
Text: salaries. However, we could save the

Speaker: NA
Text: whole of the High Commissioner's salary

Speaker: NA
Text: by not making an appointment, and,

Speaker: NA
Text: so far as the special mission is

Speaker: NA
Text: concerned, all we should have to do

Speaker: NA
Text: would - be to continue paying his

Speaker: NA
Text: ministerial salary to Mr Bruce, plus

Speaker: NA
Text: the expenses he incurs while abroad.

Speaker: NA
Text: That would he considerably less than the

Speaker: NA
Text: extra amount which he is to be paid,

Speaker: NA
Text: which is equivalent to more than £2,000

Speaker: NA
Text: per annum. We should keep that point

Speaker: NA
Text: in mind when we are told that a saving is

Speaker: NA
Text: to be made. The best way to effect a sav-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing is to make no appointment at all, but

Speaker: NA
Text: to allow Mr Collins to continue in charge

Speaker: NA
Text: at Australia House. That would not be

Speaker: NA
Text: a tremendous obligation to impose on Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Collins, who could be under the direction

Speaker: NA
Text: of Mr Bruce while the right honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member was in London, and-could be in-

Speaker: NA
Text: structed afterwards by the Cabinet. A l l

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Bruce would then be entitled to draw

Speaker: NA
Text: during his special mission would be his

Speaker: NA
Text: ministerial salary, plus an allowance for

Speaker: NA
Text: expenses. The Government proposes to

Speaker: NA
Text: provide for the right honorable member

Speaker: NA
Text: not only a ministerial salary, but over

Speaker: NA
Text: £2,000 a* year for expenses while Besident

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister in London, and yet we are told

Speaker: NA
Text: that that will effect a saving. I t will

Speaker: NA
Text: be a saving -A saving could be made by

Speaker: NA
Text: not filling the position of High Commis-

Speaker: NA
Text: sioner, and Australia would not suffer to

Speaker: NA
Text: any appreciable degree. I make that

Speaker: NA
Text: assertion advisedly.

Speaker: NA
Text: What is to be the position of the Resi-

Speaker: NA
Text: dent Minister in London? Will he take

Speaker: NA
Text: instructions from the Cabinet? He will

Speaker: NA
Text: occupy a unique position i f he does that.

Speaker: NA
Text: Will he act on his own initiative, or will

Speaker: NA
Text: he be part of the Cabinet, and keep in

Speaker: NA
Text: constant touch with Ministers in Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia by means of cablegrams and letters

Speaker: NA
Text: - a most unsatisfactory way of conduct-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing administration.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr E. J. HARRISON -Th e

Speaker: NA
Text: honorablo member himself knows that.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr SCULLIN" -S o does the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister. I have no qualms of

Speaker: NA
Text: conscience about the cablegrams sent

Speaker: NA
Text: by me while absent from Australia; I ,

Speaker: NA
Text: personally, was glad to read them

Speaker: NA
Text: when published, and to know that

Speaker: NA
Text: the public were thus apprised of

Speaker: NA
Text: my honest opinions. A Besident Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter in London could not maintain satis-

Speaker: NA
Text: factory communication with the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment in Australia for a lengthy period by

Speaker: NA
Text: means of telegrams, radiograms, or letters.

Speaker: NA
Text: Therefore, the Minister in London must

Speaker: NA
Text: act largely on his own responsibility.

Speaker: Mr WHITE
Text: Tha t is why a Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: rather than an official, is required there.

Speaker: NA
Text: MrSCULLIN - A government can

Speaker: NA
Text: give definite instructions to an official at

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia House, but it will be impossible

Speaker: NA
Text: to give instructions to a Minister. I f

Speaker: NA
Text: our representative were instructed, he

Speaker: NA
Text: would cease to be a Minister, and would

Speaker: NA
Text: become a mere official. My confention

Speaker: NA
Text: is that the right honorable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Elinders ( Mr Bruce), having completed

Speaker: NA
Text: the special mission upon which he is

Speaker: NA
Text: visiting Great Britain, should return to

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. The principles of democracy

Speaker: NA
Text: demand that the representatives of the

Speaker: NA
Text: people in this Parliament shall keep as

Speaker: NA
Text: closely as possible in touch with their

Speaker: NA
Text: electorates. To make the right honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member a permanent Besident Minister in

Speaker: NA
Text: London would be to disfranchise his con-

Speaker: NA
Text: stituents.

Speaker: Mr WHITE
Text: Hi s electorate will be well

Speaker: NA
Text: looked after in his absence.

Speaker: Mr SCULLIN
Text: It s needs were not

Speaker: NA
Text: not properly attended to when he represented

Speaker: NA
Text: it before.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is great reluctance on the part of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government to state the real reason

Speaker: NA
Text: for sending the Minister abroad. I t is

Speaker: NA
Text: said that there is special work for him

Speaker: NA
Text: to do; but that is not an adequate reason.

Speaker: NA
Text: Special work has had to be done at

Speaker: NA
Text: Ottawa, Lausanne, and Geneva. Is

Speaker: NA
Text: it seriously suggested that it is

Speaker: NA
Text: essential to have a Besident Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: in London because special work must

Speaker: NA
Text: be done there? What is the reason

Speaker: NA
Text: for sending a special Minister to

Speaker: NA
Text: London, and what will be the term

Speaker: NA
Text: of his residence there? He will be out

Speaker: NA
Text: right of touch with not only Australia, but

Speaker: NA
Text: also bis own constituents. Seeing that

Speaker: NA
Text: this bill authorizes the appointment of a

Speaker: NA
Text: Besident Minister in London, and places

Speaker: NA
Text: the imprimatur of Parliament upon such

Speaker: NA
Text: a procedure, the Opposition intends to

Speaker: NA
Text: oppose the measure. The Prime Minister,

Speaker: NA
Text: in endeavouring to find a special argu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment in support of this proposal, set out

Speaker: NA
Text: to eulogize the right honorable member

Speaker: NA
Text: who has gone abroad, and said that he

Speaker: NA
Text: was sure that he would represent Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia as well as any previous High

Speaker: NA
Text: Commissioner had done. We have

Speaker: NA
Text: not always been fortunate in the

Speaker: NA
Text: choice of our High Commissioners, and

Speaker: NA
Text: I hope that an improvement will be

Speaker: NA
Text: brought about in this instance. I t seems

Speaker: NA
Text: to me that the basis of the Prime Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter's argument is the exceptional experi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ence and profound knowledge of tlie right

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member for Flinders. 1 do not

Speaker: NA
Text: intend to indulge in personal criticism,

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly regarding a member who is

Speaker: NA
Text: absent. I read of the case for trade pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: ference presented by him on behalf of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia at Ottawa, aud I thought that

Speaker: NA
Text: he made out a strong claim. I am very

Speaker: NA
Text: doubtful, however, regarding his judg-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment as to what should be conceded by

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, and I am waiting with grave

Speaker: NA
Text: anxiety to know how his judgment has

Speaker: NA
Text: been exercised in relation to concessions.

Speaker: NA
Text: I was not particularly impressed by the

Speaker: NA
Text: right, honorable member's judgment on the

Speaker: NA
Text: economic position generally, when he was

Speaker: NA
Text: leader of a government, because I recall

Speaker: NA
Text: the warnings given by members ofmy

Speaker: NA
Text: party and by myself with regard to

Speaker: NA
Text: our trade balance in 1926, 1927

Speaker: NA
Text: and 1928. The Bruce-Page Government

Speaker: NA
Text: was then warned of the disaster likely to

Speaker: NA
Text: overtake this country i f its policy

Speaker: NA
Text: continued. I recall the light and airy

Speaker: NA
Text: way iu which those warnings were dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: missed by the.right honorable gentleman,

Speaker: NA
Text: who had not sufficient judgment to see

Speaker: NA
Text: what was likely to result from the action

Speaker: NA
Text: then taken.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am opposed to any government

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australia from abroad, and I ob-

Speaker: NA
Text: ject to the appointment of a Besident

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister in London. I shall support the

Speaker: NA
Text: visit of a member of the Cabinet on any

Speaker: NA
Text: special and important mission, and I

Speaker: NA
Text: grant that there is important, work to lie

Speaker: NA
Text: done in London by the right honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member on this occasion. I wish the right

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable gentleman every success in his

Speaker: NA
Text: mission, and I hope that the result will

Speaker: NA
Text: be a reduction of the rate of interest on

Speaker: NA
Text: our overseas loans; but, on. the comple-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of his mission, he should return to

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia to represent his constituents in

Speaker: NA
Text: this Parliament.

Speaker: Mr LATHAM
Text: Kooyong-Attorney -

Speaker: NA
Text: General) [3.58] -Th e Leader of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition ( Mr Scullin) has

Speaker: NA
Text: called attention to the obvious

Speaker: NA
Text: fact that this bill proposes a change,

Speaker: NA
Text: at least for the time being, in the character

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australia's representation in London,

Speaker: NA
Text: and has justly asked for reasons in support

Speaker: NA
Text: of that change. Those reasons were given

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Prime Minister in moving the

Speaker: NA
Text: second reading, and I propose shortly to

Speaker: NA
Text: develop one or two of them. I dissent

Speaker: NA
Text: from the view of the Leader of the Op-

Speaker: NA
Text: position as to the possibility of Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: being represented in London by some-

Speaker: NA
Text: one other than, an official. I consider it

Speaker: NA
Text: most important to have efficient repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sentation of Australia in London, repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sentation of a. character such that our

Speaker: NA
Text: representative may stand alongside, and,

Speaker: NA
Text: I hope, often above, the representatives

Speaker: NA
Text: of other countries. To have an official

Speaker: NA
Text: in a world centre such as London as the

Speaker: NA
Text: representative of a dominion or a foreign

Speaker: NA
Text: country is particularly unfortunate in

Speaker: NA
Text: many respects. I t necessarily and inevi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tably results in the impression being con-

Speaker: NA
Text: veyed that the country so represented is

Speaker: NA
Text: of second-rate importance, and unable to

Speaker: NA
Text: obtain any one of distinction to represent

Speaker: NA
Text: it abroad. The Australian representa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive in London has a tremendous field

Speaker: NA
Text: for useful activity, and is able to exercise

Speaker: NA
Text: a wide influence in promoting the well-

Speaker: NA
Text: being of our' people. Discussions with

Speaker: NA
Text: people abroad may at the present time

Speaker: NA
Text: turn largely on finance. But there are

Speaker: NA
Text: other vitally important subjects. Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia's principal markets are in

Speaker: NA
Text: Great Britain, and i t is important

Speaker: NA
Text: that we hold and extend them. The com-

Speaker: NA
Text: petition for them is intense at the present

Speaker: NA
Text: time, and the Commonwealth must be

Speaker: NA
Text: kept well before the minds of the British

Speaker: NA
Text: people in order that we may have the full

Speaker: NA
Text: advantage of not only the quality of our

Speaker: NA
Text: products, but also that sentimental in-

Speaker: NA
Text: terest in the dominions which is of great

Speaker: NA
Text: importance to - Australia's exporting

Speaker: NA
Text: trade.

Speaker: Mr GREGORY
Text: W e want a business

Speaker: NA
Text: man with commercial capacity rather

Speaker: NA
Text: than a politician.

Speaker: Mr LATHAM
Text: A representative

Speaker: NA
Text: whose ability and distinction appeal to

Speaker: NA
Text: the minds of the British people is worth

Speaker: NA
Text: a great deal more than a mere office man,

Speaker: NA
Text: however great may be his commercial

Speaker: NA
Text: knowledge. Of course, we must have a

Speaker: NA
Text: well-qualified commercial staff, but we

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly need a man whose eminence

Speaker: NA
Text: catches the public imagination, and who

Speaker: NA
Text: is able to make a contribution to the

Speaker: NA
Text: public life of not only the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth, but also the Mother Country

Speaker: NA
Text: itself. Great endeavours have been made

Speaker: NA
Text: to increase the consumption of dominion

Speaker: NA
Text: products in Great Britain, and excellent

Speaker: NA
Text: work to that end has been done by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Empire Marketing Board. Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: must do everything possible to maintain

Speaker: NA
Text: its commercial reputation and prestige

Speaker: NA
Text: abroad, for I assure honorable members

Speaker: NA
Text: that prestige is a highly important

Speaker: NA
Text: element in both finance and trade.

Speaker: NA
Text: This bill is not brought forward for

Speaker: NA
Text: the purpose of introducing a^new general

Speaker: NA
Text: principle. From time to time the relative

Speaker: NA
Text: advantages of a High Commissioner or a

Speaker: NA
Text: Besident Minister to represent dominions

Speaker: NA
Text: in London have been discussed. I have

Speaker: NA
Text: never accepted j t as a general principle

Speaker: NA
Text: that Australia would be most effectively

Speaker: NA
Text: represented by a Besident Minister.

Speaker: NA
Text: While that system would have advan-

Speaker: NA
Text: tages it would have also great disadvan-

Speaker: NA
Text: tages. I t is true that Canada has on

Speaker: NA
Text: occasions been represented by a Besident

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister, but it is very much easier for

Speaker: NA
Text: him to keep in direct contact with his

Speaker: NA
Text: colleagues than it would be for an Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian Minister resident in London.

Speaker: NA
Text: Amongst the advantages of having a

Speaker: NA
Text: Besident Minister would be that he would

Speaker: NA
Text: have an authority abroad which no other

Speaker: NA
Text: appointee could have. He would be able

Speaker: NA
Text: to speak directly for his Government, and

Speaker: NA
Text: in all negotiations would achieve more

Speaker: NA
Text: a shorter space of time than would any

Speaker: NA
Text: -official. He would also be in closer

Speaker: NA
Text: -contact with his Government.

Speaker: NA
Text: element of authority which he would en-

Speaker: NA
Text: joy would play an important part in

Speaker: NA
Text: dealings with representatives of other

Speaker: NA
Text: countries. When it is known that the

Speaker: NA
Text: representative of a dominion has full

Speaker: NA
Text: authority to aet for the Government of

Speaker: NA
Text: that country, much more can be achieved

Speaker: NA
Text: than when discussions with a High Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: missioner or other official are known to

Speaker: NA
Text: be merely preliminary and provisional.

Speaker: NA
Text: On the other hand,' a system of represenI

Speaker: NA
Text: tation in London by a Besident Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: would possess distinct disadvantages. I t

Speaker: NA
Text: could not be adopted as a general prin-

Speaker: NA
Text: ciple, because often it would be im-

Speaker: NA
Text: possible for a Minister to be absent for

Speaker: NA
Text: a considerable length of time from this

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament and from his constituency.

Speaker: NA
Text: Therefore, the innovation now proposed

Speaker: NA
Text: may be regarded as only an experiment

Speaker: NA
Text: to meet special circumstances. I n the

Speaker: NA
Text: highly-important financial negotiations

Speaker: NA
Text: that must be conducted during the next

Speaker: NA
Text: few months, it is of the utmost

Speaker: NA
Text: importance that the man who speaks

Speaker: NA
Text: on behalf of Australia shall be vested

Speaker: NA
Text: with the maximum of authority.

Speaker: NA
Text: Direct conversational dealing is worth

Speaker: NA
Text: many months of indirect negotia-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion through an official. The Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: without Portfolio ( Mr Bruce) possesses

Speaker: NA
Text: special qualifications for doing the work

Speaker: NA
Text: for which he has been appointed, and it

Speaker: NA
Text: would be very difficult for the Official

Speaker: NA
Text: Secretary, competent as he is, to achieve

Speaker: NA
Text: as much as the man with the status of a

Speaker: NA
Text: former Prime Minister and late Assistant-

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer of the Commonwealth. The

Speaker: NA
Text: loan conversions will involve mainly

Speaker: NA
Text: direct negotiation with individuals and

Speaker: NA
Text: institutions, and as a result of my own

Speaker: NA
Text: experience in London recently, I am con-

Speaker: NA
Text: vinced that the Minister will achieve

Speaker: NA
Text: much more than could any official, how-

Speaker: NA
Text: ever competent. The passage of this bill

Speaker: NA
Text: is necessary to enable the right honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Flinders to control the stalf

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australia House. Its operation is

Speaker: NA
Text: limited to two years, and the Minister in

Speaker: NA
Text: London will exercise the functions men-

Speaker: NA
Text: tioned in the bill only during the pleasure

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Governor-General. The object of

Speaker: NA
Text: that provision is to put it beyond doubt

Speaker: NA
Text: in that any appointment under this legisla-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion will not be even remotely binding on

Speaker: NA
Text: any subsequent administration -

Speaker: Mr GREGORY
Text: Wha t is the salary of

Speaker: NA
Text: the High Commissioner?

Speaker: Mr LATHAM
Text: Th e salary is £3,000,

Speaker: NA
Text: plus an allowance of £2,000, both amounts

Speaker: NA
Text: being subject to a 25 per cent, reduction

Speaker: NA
Text: under the financial emergency legislation.

Speaker: NA
Text: While the right honorable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Flinders is doing the work of the High

Speaker: NA
Text: Commissioner, lie will receive these re-

Speaker: NA
Text: duced amounts, and a saving equivalent

Speaker: NA
Text: to his ministerial salary will be effected.

Speaker: NA
Text: ask the House to accept the bill, not as

Speaker: NA
Text: a measure introducing a new principle,

Speaker: NA
Text: but because it will enable us to have the

Speaker: NA
Text: benefit of the services of the right honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Flinders in London in

Speaker: NA
Text: connexion with highly important financial

Speaker: NA
Text: transactions during the next few months.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government does not intend to pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: long this appointment beyond what the

Speaker: NA
Text: necessities of the case demand-. I n con-

Speaker: NA
Text: nexion with these matters, it is very often

Speaker: NA
Text: difficult to state publicly what the neces-

Speaker: NA
Text: sities of the case are, because financial

Speaker: NA
Text: transactions may depend upon personal

Speaker: NA
Text: negotiations, sometimes intimate, and

Speaker: NA
Text: always private, which, would be rendered

Speaker: NA
Text: abortive i f publicity were given to them.?

Speaker: NA
Text: I consider that the Commonwealth is for-

Speaker: NA
Text: tunate in being able to obtain the services

Speaker: NA
Text: of the right honorable member for Flin-

Speaker: NA
Text: ders in London at this juncture, and for

Speaker: NA
Text: the special task which he has been asked

Speaker: NA
Text: to undertake.

Speaker: Dr EARLE PAGE
Text: Cowper) [4.10] -

Speaker: NA
Text: I congratulate the Government upon the

Speaker: NA
Text: step it has taken. My only criticism of

Speaker: NA
Text: the bill is that it does not go far enough.

Speaker: NA
Text: I object to the limitation of the appoint-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment to two years; that restriction could

Speaker: NA
Text: have been imposed later i f the experiment

Speaker: NA
Text: proved unsatisfactory. I am disappointed

Speaker: NA
Text: also that there is no provision for negotia-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion .with the States for the abolition of

Speaker: NA
Text: the office of Agdnt-General, so that Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia might be wholly represented by a

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister of this Parliament.

Speaker: Mr GABB
Text: Thos e positions are kept

Speaker: NA
Text: as political plums.

Speaker: Dr EARLE PAGE
Text: I welcome the

Speaker: NA
Text: policy contained i n this bill because,

Speaker: NA
Text: while it continues, the position of High

Speaker: NA
Text: Commissioner will no longer be a political

Speaker: NA
Text: plum. I have no complaint to make of

Speaker: NA
Text: the gentlemen who have filled that office

Speaker: NA
Text: in the past. All had distinguished them-

Speaker: NA
Text: selves in the public life of Australia, but

Speaker: NA
Text: none of them returned to this Parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: to enrich it with the increased 'knowledge

Speaker: NA
Text: which they must have gained by their

Speaker: NA
Text: residence and contacts abroad. I n future,

Speaker: NA
Text: if the system of appointing a Resident

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister in London be continued, a mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber of this Parliament will discharge that

Speaker: NA
Text: duty, and he will be obliged to return here

Speaker: NA
Text: to give to Parliament and to his con-

Speaker: NA
Text: stituents an account of his stewardship.

Speaker: NA
Text: One reason why I have always advocated

Speaker: NA
Text: the appointment of a Resident Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: in London is the .need for widening the

Speaker: NA
Text: circle of men in this Parliament who have

Speaker: NA
Text: definite and intimate kaowledge of con-

Speaker: NA
Text: ditions and governing authorities on the

Speaker: NA
Text: other side of the world. I f there is one

Speaker: NA
Text: matter in respect of which Australia com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pares unfavorably with some of the other

Speaker: NA
Text: dominions, it is the failure of its people

Speaker: NA
Text: to realize the international position they

Speaker: NA
Text: have attained since the Great War. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth must have international

Speaker: NA
Text: contacts. The increasing extent and dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tribution of its trade make it essential

Speaker: NA
Text: that this Parliament shall contain men

Speaker: NA
Text: with experience abroad. I have always

Speaker: NA
Text: hoped that the constant return to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth Parliament of men who

Speaker: NA
Text: had served for a year or so as Resident

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister abroad would gradually build

Speaker: NA
Text: up from all parties-becaus e as govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments changed the ministerial representa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion abroad would change-committee s

Speaker: NA
Text: of members, qualified to advise govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments in regard to external affairs, thus

Speaker: NA
Text: creating a definite interest in Imperial

Speaker: NA
Text: and foreign policy. A striking feature

Speaker: NA
Text: of the debates of this Parliament is the

Speaker: NA
Text: entire absence of comment on foreign re-

Speaker: NA
Text: lations ; we seem to be absorbed in our in-

Speaker: NA
Text: ternal politics.

Speaker: Mr BEASLEY
Text: W e do not get a chance

Speaker: NA
Text: to discuss other matters.

Speaker: Dr EARLE PAGE
Text: Th e character

Speaker: NA
Text: of the business-paper does not vary much

Speaker: NA
Text: with changes of government. One ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: planation is that there are not in this

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament sufficient men who have had

Speaker: NA
Text: extensive experience abroad and made

Speaker: NA
Text: -intimate contacts with governments and

Speaker: NA
Text: public men in other countries. Although

Speaker: NA
Text: I have always advocated the appointment

Speaker: NA
Text: of a Besident Minister in London, there

Speaker: NA
Text: was, in the past, one valid objection to it,

Speaker: NA
Text: namely, the difficulty of maintaining close

Speaker: NA
Text: contact between the Minister overseas

Speaker: NA
Text: and the Government here, but since the'

Speaker: NA
Text: invention of wireless telephony that dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: advantage has been removed. There is

Speaker: NA
Text: no reason why the Minister overseas

Speaker: NA
Text: should not, i f necessary, be in daily per-

Speaker: NA
Text: sonal contact with the Government of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia that will remove the

Speaker: NA
Text: grave danger that there was previously,

Speaker: NA
Text: of the representative overseas committing

Speaker: NA
Text: his Government, without previous dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: cussion with it, to an undesirable policy.

Speaker: NA
Text: Another reason why there should be a

Speaker: NA
Text: Besident Minister representing the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government of Australia in Great

Speaker: NA
Text: Britain, is that the status of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Governor-General has altered during the

Speaker: NA
Text: past few years. At present that office

Speaker: NA
Text: is held by an Australian who has not had

Speaker: NA
Text: the opportunity that previous Governor-

Speaker: NA
Text: Generals had of being in touch with the

Speaker: NA
Text: British Government or with His Majesty

Speaker: NA

Text: have a great respect for the knowledge of

Text: detail possessed by the right honorable

Text: in member for Flinders-bu t a. broad grasp

Text: by of Australia's position that is required

Text: by a Minister going to represent Australia

Text: overseas. Who would be the more

Text: powerful or more impressive advocate of

Text: Australia, of her resources, of her

Text: honorable record for prompt payment

Speaker: NA
Text: or some Commonwealth public servant,

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: great the respect in which Ave hold him?

Text: Collins himself, that our financial adviser

Text: in London could do the Avork required at

Text: the present time so satisfactorily as could

Speaker: NA
Text: We have already read something, par-

Text: ticularly in the financial press of

Speaker: NA
Text: England, of the good effect produced in

Text: financial circles by the advocacy of Aus-

Text: ( Mr Latham) Avhen he was recently in

Text: London. We have learned how he was

Text: able most effectively to dispose of certain

Text: ill-informed and groundless prejudices

Text: against Australia and her methods of

Text: finance. I believe that the right hon-

Text: task as well as any man could. The Go-

Text: He is a well-known figure, he has an

Text: international reputation, he has a per-

Text: institutions, which must be of in-

Text: calculable value to Australia Avhen we are

Text: London market.

Text: terial authority which he will possess

Text: not be overlooked. The Deputy Leader

Text: of the Opposition said that Mr Bruce's

Text: tralian outlook. This is demonstrated by

Text: the present personnel of this House.

Speaker: NA

Text: spoke of marketing arrangements over-

Text: seas, and appears to think it absurd that

Text: MT. Bruce should be expected to do any-

Text: thing to advance Australia's trade in

Text: Great Britain. His argument reminded

Text: -members of certain trade unions that one

Text: man must do only one thing; that, for in-

Text: stance, a plumber must never touch any-

Text: thing which could be done by a carpenter.

Text: thing and everything to advance Aus-

Text: everything else. We know that iu 1923 i t

Text: Avas this same gentleman, the right

Text: important exporting industries by obtain-

Text: ence for dried fruits, wines, and sugar,

Text: of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition,

Text: Avho has been at such pains to belittle

Text: Mr Bruce.

Speaker: NA
Text: Some of the gibes of honorable mem-

Text: bers i n respect of the emoluments of the

Text: High Commissioner are very paltry.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Prime Minister has shown that there

Text: will be an actual saving as the result of

Text: the neAv arrangement; but, even if .there

Text: undertake, and the enormous benefits

Text: which will accrue to Australia i f he is

Text: successful, we realize IIOAV petty are com-

Text: plaints about the salary of the Besident

Text: Minister in London. Consider, for

Text: instance, the first task which Mr.

Text: Bruce will undertake-th e conversion of

Text: a loan of £13,000,000 for New South

Text: Wales, which is falling due in "NoAem- r

Text: ber. I f i t were possiblefor Australia,

Text: owing to the efforts of a man of the

Text: standing of Mr Bruce, to secure terms

Text: only 2s. 6d. per cent, lower in the interest'

Text: payable on the loan, it would mean a

Text: saving of £16,000 a year. I do not

Text: think i t would be expecting too much, or

Text: exaggerating the possibilities of the

Text: situation, to say that Mr Bruce might

Text: - be able to obtain that additional advan-

Text: tage when another man could not. Then

Text: there i3 a larger conversion which it'might

Speaker: NA
Text: 'he advantageous to undertake later. We

Text: were told by the Prime Minister in his

Text: budget speech that, of the £474,000,000

Speaker: NA
Text: which we owed in Great Britain apart

Text: from war debt, about £307,000,000 was

Text: borrowed at 5 per cent, and over. No

Speaker: NA
Text: less than £93,000,000 was at more

Speaker: NA
Text: than 5 per cent., and up to 6£

Speaker: NA
Text: ;.per cent. We were also reminded

Speaker: NA
Text: last week that we have current option

Speaker: NA
Text: conversion rights over £96,000,000 worth

Speaker: NA
Text: -of our overseas debt, on which we pay

Text: 5 per cent, and up to 6-J por cent,

Speaker: NA
Text: interest. There is nothing to prevent us

Text: from negotiating with the overseas bond-

Text: holders at the present time, or at any

Speaker: NA
Text: I f Mr Bruce were able to obtain an

Text: advantage of 2s. 6d. per cent, less interest

Text: on £96,000,000 worth of debt, that alone

Text: year to Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government could not have made a

Speaker: NA
Text: better choice for this position, and I

Text: support the bill.

Speaker: Mr WHITE
Text: Balaclava) [5.12] -I t

Speaker: NA
Text: is hardly necessary to say anything in

Speaker: NA
Text: support of this bill, because the appoint-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of such a man as Mr Bruce is

Speaker: NA
Text: obviously a good one. He has peculiar

Speaker: NA
Text: characteristics, he has travelled, he is

Speaker: NA
Text: educated, and he is, above all

Speaker: NA
Text: things, a gentleman, which one can-

Speaker: NA
Text: not say of some of the representatives

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australia who have been sent

Speaker: NA
Text: abroad in the past. I have risen chiefly

Speaker: NA
Text: because of the attacks made on Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bruce by the honorable member for East.

Speaker: NA
Text: Sydney ( Mr Ward), the honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber for West Sydney ( Mr Beasley) and

Speaker: NA
Text: the Deputy Loader of the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Forde). The Leader of the Oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sition ( Mr Scullin) said that Mr Bruce

Speaker: NA
Text: had carried Australia to disaster, and

Speaker: NA
Text: treated the warnings of various persons-

Speaker: NA
Text: himself included, I suppose-i n an airy

Speaker: NA
Text: manner; and that, consequently, he

Speaker: NA
Text: was thrown from office in 1929.

Speaker: NA
Text: Honorable members know well that

Speaker: NA
Text: the main issue at that election was

Speaker: NA
Text: arbitration-th e removal of a great

Speaker: NA
Text: many petty industrial matters from

Speaker: NA
Text: the jurisdiction of the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth Arbitration Court to that of State

Speaker: NA
Text: tribunals. The Leader of the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: used all his oratory on that occasion to

Speaker: NA
Text: defeat the right honorable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Flinders ( Mr Bruce), stating that there

Speaker: NA
Text: was no need to economize, no need to cut

Speaker: NA
Text: down the costs of industry by reforming

Speaker: NA
Text: the arbitration system. But what'did the

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition and his sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: porters do after they had brought about

Speaker: NA
Text: the fall of Mr Bruce and his Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment? They found themselves up against

Speaker: NA
Text: financial and economic problems, and

Speaker: NA
Text: were compelled to bring in wage reduction

Speaker: NA
Text: bills, which cut the earnings of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Avorkers very substantially. Yet they

Speaker: NA
Text: have the audacity now to charge Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bruce with, having neglected his duty,

Speaker: NA
Text: the when, they themselves were prepared to

Speaker: NA
Text: bribe the people by offering what they

Speaker: NA
Text: could noi deliver. For six years, the

Speaker: NA
Text: right honorable member acquitted him-

Speaker: NA
Text: self honorably as leader of the Bruce-

Speaker: NA
Text: Page Government, whose term of office

Speaker: NA
Text: was one of the most prosperous periods in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's history.

Speaker: NA
Text: The right honorable gentleman has

Speaker: NA
Text: been attacked to-day because it happens

Speaker: NA
Text: that his interests are not entirely politi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cal; but I claim that one of the greatest

Speaker: NA
Text: curses in Australia, to-day is the profes-

Speaker: NA
Text: sional politician. Many honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers on the other side of the House re-

Speaker: NA
Text: present that class. They have the gift of

Speaker: NA
Text: the gab, and having acted as union secre-

Speaker: NA
Text: taries, often through being indifferent

Speaker: NA
Text: tradesmen, they are regarded as suitable

Speaker: NA
Text: candidates for parliamentary honours.

Speaker: NA
Text: These men have to do-as they are told;

Speaker: NA
Text: yet they pose in this Parliament as the

Speaker: NA
Text: representatives of a democratic move-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. The man who has been criticized

Speaker: NA
Text: in this House to-day has shown his

Speaker: NA
Text: ability in other than political walks of

Speaker: NA
Text: life. In reply to the gibe that he does

Speaker: NA
Text: not know this country so well as some

Speaker: NA
Text: petty-minded Australians do, I point out

Speaker: NA
Text: that the fact that he went abroad for

Speaker: NA
Text: some of his education stands to his credit,

Speaker: NA
Text: rather than to his detriment. He spent

Speaker: NA
Text: several years in doing his part during a

Speaker: NA
Text: national crisis, while certain other hon-

Speaker: NA
Text: orable members seemed not to remember

Speaker: NA
Text: to do so. That, too, may be said to the

Speaker: NA
Text: credit of the right honorable member.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honorable member for West Sydney

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Beasley) remarked that when the

Speaker: NA
Text: right honorable member was defeated in

Speaker: NA
Text: Flinders, ho left. Australia, and took no

Speaker: NA
Text: part in assisting to get this country out

Speaker: NA
Text: of its difficulties. I am in a position to

Speaker: NA
Text: state that he could then have had a safe

Speaker: NA
Text: seat in this Parliament, had he chosen to

Speaker: NA
Text: take it. I accidentally met him when he

Speaker: NA
Text: knew that the figures in his own elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: torate were against him. On that occa-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion, I had been a member of this House

Speaker: NA
Text: for only three or four weeks and had suc-

Speaker: NA
Text: cessfully faced a second election, but in

Speaker: NA
Text: view of the attack made upon Mr Bruce

Speaker: NA
Text: by honorable members opposite, I make"

Speaker: NA
Text: no apology for saying that I offered to

Speaker: NA
Text: resign i f he cared to take my seat in

Speaker: NA
Text: Balaclava.

Speaker: Mr GANDER
Text: Anothe r dummy!

Speaker: Mr WHITE
Text: I know that the honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Beid ( Mr Gander) is

Speaker: NA
Text: a seat-warmer for the ex-Premier of New

Speaker: NA
Text: South Wales, but, as I have pointed out,

Speaker: NA
Text: when I made that offer I had heen a

Speaker: NA
Text: member for only a few weeks, and I

Speaker: NA
Text: realized that it was a tragedy for the

Speaker: NA
Text: services of a man of the calibre of Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bruce to be lost to Australia. The right

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable gentleman said that he was

Speaker: NA
Text: going on a holiday, but he promised that

Speaker: NA
Text: when he returned from Great Britain, he

Speaker: NA
Text: would fight for his old seat, and win it

Speaker: NA
Text: back. The honorable member for Mel-

Speaker: NA
Text: bourne Ports ( Mr Holloway), who left

Speaker: NA
Text: the Blinders seat for a safer electorate,

Speaker: NA
Text: can tell us whether the right honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Flinders carried out that

Speaker: NA
Text: promise. The 'honorable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: West Sydney remarked that Mr Willis

Text: had complained that the United Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: party had " cruelled the pitch " for him,

Speaker: NA
Text: because it refused to i>e a party to repu-

Speaker: NA
Text: diation of overseas interest payments, and

Speaker: NA
Text: that he could have secured lower interest

Speaker: NA
Text: rates overseas i f the Lang policy had

Text: been adopted. The honorable member

Text: for West Sydney preferred an importa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of the type of Mr Willis to an honest

Speaker: NA
Text: and. influential man like Mr Bruce.

Speaker: Mr GANDER
Text: Doe s not the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member believe in importation?.

Speaker: Mr WHITE
Text: W e could well do with

Speaker: NA
Text: the exportation of some of the " reds"

Speaker: NA
Text: and their associates.

Speaker: NA
Text: I regret that a most worthy member

Speaker: NA
Text: of this House has been unfairly criticized.

Speaker: NA
Text: The international situation is most com-

Speaker: NA
Text: plex. Affairs in Germany have come to

Speaker: NA
Text: such a pass that there may be civil war

Speaker: NA
Text: in that country, and Bussia is mysterious

Speaker: NA
Text: and menacing. Honorable members

Speaker: NA
Text: opposite address each other as comrades,

Speaker: NA
Text: and profess to believe in tbe brotherhood

Speaker: NA
Text: of man, but in the arena of domestic

Speaker: NA
Text: politics, they fight bitterly between them-

Speaker: NA
Text: selves. Paradoxically, they favour a

Speaker: NA
Text: high tariff, which makes a country

Speaker: NA
Text: selfishly national, and is often the cause

Speaker: NA
Text: of international disputes. The party

Speaker: NA
Text: opposite is alive only to the petty, local

Speaker: NA
Text: interests of Australia, but we are fortu-

Speaker: NA
Text: nate in having, in Mr Bruce, a man who

Speaker: NA
Text: sees affairs in their imperial and interna-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional aspects. I support the bill.

Speaker: Mr BLAKELEY
Text: Darling) [5.21] - 1

Speaker: NA
Text: oppose this measure. I do not say that

Speaker: NA
Text: my opposition to i t would have dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: appeared i f the Prime Minister ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Lyons), the Attorney-General ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Latham), and several of those support-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the bill had been more frank in ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: plaining the supposed necessity for it .

Speaker: NA
Text: Its real object seems to be shrouded in

Speaker: NA
Text: mystery. Apparently, no good reason can

Speaker: NA
Text: be advanced for clothing the Besident

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister in London with the powers of

Speaker: NA
Text: the High Commissioner. As a matter of

Speaker: NA
Text: fact, under present conditions it is not

Speaker: NA
Text: necessary to have a High Commissioner

Speaker: NA
Text: in London at all. Mr J. B. Collins has

Speaker: NA
Text: practically carried out the work of that

Speaker: NA
Text: officer for many years. Judging by the

Speaker: NA
Text: powers proposed to be given to the right

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member for Flinders ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bruce), under this more or less spectacu-

Speaker: NA
Text: lar measure, it would seem that the House

Speaker: NA
Text: has not been informed of the real reason

Speaker: NA
Text: for the bill.

Speaker: NA
Text: I do not intend to make a personal

Speaker: NA
Text: attack on Mr Bruce in his absence, but

Speaker: NA
Text: I am entitled, I think, to offer criticism

Speaker: NA
Text: of a political nature. The injurious

Speaker: NA
Text: effect on Australia of the administration

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Bruce-Page Government is still

Speaker: NA
Text: remembered, and, unfortunately, this

Speaker: NA
Text: country, will for many years have

Speaker: NA
Text: to bear the burden which that

Speaker: NA
Text: Government imposed upon it.. I l

Speaker: NA
Text: had an un-Australian outlook, for

Speaker: NA
Text: it adopted a policy of borrowing

Speaker: NA
Text: and buying abroad. Our secondary

Speaker: NA
Text: industries and our finances were crippled

Speaker: NA
Text: during its regime. When, in 1929, i t

Speaker: NA
Text: ignoniiniously went out of office, it was

Speaker: NA
Text: generally regarded as a Ministry which

Speaker: NA
Text: had administered the finances of this

Speaker: NA
Text: country unwisely. . During thisdebate,

Speaker: NA
Text: many encomiums have been heaped upon

Speaker: NA
Text: the right honorable member for Flinders.

Speaker: NA
Text: One can readily find a reason for that.

Speaker: NA
Text: When 'he Comes back, in all probability

Speaker: NA
Text: he will be in a' position to reward, those

Speaker: NA
Text: who have defended him in his absence

Speaker: NA
Text: from the charges levelled against him as

Speaker: NA
Text: a public financier. One Can appreciate

Speaker: NA
Text: the desire of certain honorable members

Speaker: NA
Text: to stand in well with a man who will

Speaker: NA
Text: probably occupy a high position in this

Speaker: NA
Text: country before the expiration of the

Speaker: NA
Text: twelve months for which he is to be

Speaker: NA
Text: appointed Besident Minister in London.

Speaker: NA
Text: His first duty, it seems to me, is to re-

Speaker: NA
Text: habilitate himself in the eyes of the people

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australia, and that will be a difficult

Speaker: NA
Text: job. Much has be6n said to-day of

Speaker: NA
Text: his capacity as an administrator, but I

Speaker: NA
Text: claim that during his term of office as

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister he showed blundering in-

Speaker: NA
Text: capacityj and a total disregard for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Welfare of Australian industries. There

Speaker: NA
Text: was lavish expenditure during his regime;

Speaker: NA
Text: public money was wasted,- and from ten

Speaker: NA
Text: to fifteen years will be required to enable

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commonwealth to recover from

Speaker: NA
Text: the bankrupt condition in which he

Speaker: NA
Text: left it. This is the man who is held

Speaker: NA
Text: up to-day as the only person suit-

Speaker: NA
Text: able for the special mission on which he

Speaker: NA
Text: has been sent to London. As a matter of

Speaker: NA
Text: fact, the job for which he is ostensibly

Speaker: NA
Text: going there, has already been done.

Speaker: NA
Text: What I am afraid of is that the right

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member, with his kindly regard

Speaker: NA
Text: for the overseas financiers and the bond-

Speaker: NA
Text: holders, will not strike such a bargain

Speaker: NA
Text: for Australia as could be obtained by a

Speaker: NA
Text: representative other than himself.

Speaker: NA
Text: my opinion, he has neither the necessary

Speaker: NA
Text: capacity, nor the temperament required

Speaker: NA
Text: to enable him to carry out delicate

Speaker: NA
Text: financial negotiations. The right honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member has not an Australian out-

Speaker: NA
Text: look. I speak as the result of about

Speaker: NA
Text: ten years' experience of him in the public

Speaker: NA
Text: life of this country, and that is also the

Speaker: NA
Text: conclusion which many thousands of

Speaker: NA
Text: people in Australia have reached

Speaker: NA
Text: ing him. Owing to his mismanagement

Speaker: NA
Text: of the finances of the Commonweal th,

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot accept him as the plenipotentiary

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr lilakeleu.

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australia. No doubt, the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: thinks that i t is doing right in selecting

Speaker: NA
Text: the right honorable member for this work,

Speaker: NA
Text: but the Opposition is entitled to protest

Speaker: NA
Text: against his selection to carry out the con-

Speaker: NA
Text: version of Australia's' overseas loans. I f

Speaker: NA
Text: the main reason for the appointment of

Speaker: NA
Text: the right honorable gentleman to this

Speaker: NA
Text: high position is not his personal rehabili-

Speaker: NA
Text: tation in the eyes of the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: people, one wonders-an d I regret that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Prime Minister' was not more frank-

Speaker: NA
Text: for whom the right honorable gentleman

Speaker: NA
Text: is- " seat-warming " in Flinders. Some

Speaker: NA
Text: talk has been indulged in about "seat-

Speaker: NA
Text: warming " this afternoon. Why did not

Speaker: NA
Text: the honorable member for Balaclava ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: White) enlighten the House on this

Speaker: NA
Text: matter? I have no doubt that the right

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member for Flinders is very

Speaker: NA
Text: happy in' his new position. A ll his

Speaker: NA
Text: business interests, or at least the greatei

Speaker: NA
Text: part of them, lie in London, and they

Speaker: NA
Text: have caused him great concern in the last

Speaker: NA
Text: couple of years; in fact he had to hurry

Speaker: NA
Text: to London some time ago to take over a

Speaker: NA
Text: more or less staggering concern.

Speaker: Mr WHITE
Text: Th e honorable member

Speaker: NA
Text: promised not to be personal.

Speaker: Mr BLAKELEY
Text: M y criticism is

Speaker: NA
Text: not personal; I am merely reminding

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable members of something

Speaker: NA
Text: which the right honorable member

Speaker: NA
Text: himself said in this House. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is common knowledge that the firm

Speaker: NA
Text: of Paterson, Laing and Bruce has suffered

Speaker: NA

Speaker: Dr MALONEY
Text: Melbourne) [6.0] -

Speaker: NA
Text: This measure is .intituled " A bill to

Speaker: NA
Text: amend the High Commissioner Act

Speaker: NA
Text: 1909 ". I accept the statement of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister ( Mr Lyons) that if i t

Speaker: NA
Text: is agreed to, a considerable sum will be

Speaker: NA
Text: saved. I only regret that an attempt is

Speaker: NA
Text: not being, made to save still more. I

Speaker: NA
Text: have known every High Commissioner

Speaker: NA
Text: for Australia. I was in London when

Speaker: NA
Text: sites for Australia House were being

Speaker: NA
Text: inspected. One site offered faced Trafal-

Speaker: NA
Text: gar Square. I t had a wide frontage but a

Speaker: NA
Text: shallow depth. My old friend, Sir George

Speaker: NA
Text: Reid, observed concerning it, " Too much

Speaker: NA
Text: face, and too little belly to build Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: House on". Subsequently, the present

Speaker: NA
Text: site was chosen. Sir George Reid was the

Speaker: NA
Text: first High Commissioner, and a very good

Speaker: NA
Text: one he was. Next came Mr Andrew

Speaker: NA
Text: Fisher; then Sir Joseph Cook, and then

Speaker: NA
Text: Sir Granville Ryrie. I t will be noticed

Speaker: NA
Text: that all the occupants of this position,

Speaker: NA
Text: except Andrew Fisher, were decorated

Speaker: NA
Text: with the tuppeny-ha'penny tin-pot thing

Speaker: NA
Text: termed a title. Only Andrew Fisher

Speaker: NA
Text: was plain Mister. But he dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: charged his duties as well

Speaker: NA
Text: any other occupant of the office. I like Sir

Speaker: NA
Text: Granville Byrie, because he is a plain,

Speaker: NA
Text: blunt man who speaks from his heart.

Speaker: NA
Text: He said when he was appointed that he

Speaker: NA
Text: did not know why the honour had been

Speaker: NA
Text: conferred upon him, and added that he

Speaker: NA
Text: would do his level best. He certainly

Speaker: NA
Text: made friends in South Africa when he

Speaker: NA
Text: told the Boers that they were brave men

Speaker: NA
Text: who had fought a desperate fight for free-

Speaker: NA
Text: dom.

Speaker: NA
Text: I oppose this bill. I t is an infamy, in

Speaker: NA
Text: present circumstances, to inflict upon the

Speaker: NA
Text: great Australian public the heavy expense

Speaker: NA
Text: which this office involves. I n answer to

Speaker: NA
Text: a question which I asked in this House

Speaker: NA
Text: on the 20th September, 1928, I was told

Speaker: NA
Text: that up to the 30th June, 1928, the build-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing had cost £621,700, and that the site

Speaker: NA
Text: had cost £379,800, making, in all,

Speaker: NA
Text: £1,001,500. The administrative costs

Speaker: NA
Text: then were £720,602.

Text: able increase on the cost.
