Text: We know very well that in consequence

Speaker: NA
Text: of the high taxation in England many

Speaker: NA
Text: aristocratic homes have been sold. Still,

Speaker: NA
Text: I do not think we would lose much, if

Speaker: NA
Text: anything, if we were to sell Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: House even now. We have all heard

Speaker: NA
Text: the old adage that promises, like

Speaker: NA
Text: pie-crusts, are made to be broken,

Speaker: NA
Text: and another equally common saying

Speaker: NA
Text: that the path to hell is paved with good

Speaker: NA
Text: intentions. I t will be remembered that

Speaker: NA
Text: just before the consummation of federa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, when we were discussing, on the

Speaker: NA
Text: public platforms of this country, the bene-

Speaker: NA
Text: fits that would flow to Australia i f the

Speaker: NA
Text: colonies federated, it was often said that

Speaker: NA
Text: one result of federation would mean that

Speaker: NA
Text: we should be able to do with one agent-

Speaker: NA
Text: general for the Commonwealth and the

Speaker: NA
Text: States, whereas then six were needed,

Speaker: NA
Text: one for each State. I t was actually

Speaker: NA
Text: as promised that we should have only one

Speaker: NA
Text: agent-general, but the promise was uot

Speaker: NA
Text: fulfilled. A l l the States still have their

Speaker: NA
Text: own agents-general.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr AacHDALB PAKKHILI, -Oh , no!

Speaker: NA
Text: New South Wales has abolished the office,'

Speaker: NA
Text: and so has Tasmania.

Speaker: Dr MALONEY
Text: Well , we still have

Speaker: NA
Text: four agents-general too many. I believe

Speaker: NA
Text: that i f the people of Australia were con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sulted by ballot.they would indicate by

Speaker: NA
Text: an overwhelming majority that the office

Speaker: NA
Text: of State agent-general should be abol-

Speaker: NA
Text: ished in every case.

Speaker: NA
Text: In reply to my inquiry as to the num-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber of persons employed at Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: House, I obtained the following figures:-

Speaker: NA
Text: Temporary, 313 j permanent, 29; total

Speaker: NA
Text: 342. I was also informed that only 58

Speaker: NA
Text: of these were Australians. I have no

Speaker: NA
Text: objection to British people. My mother

Speaker: NA
Text: was an English woman, and I love the

Speaker: NA
Text: land from which she came. But I think

Speaker: NA
Text: more Australians should be employed at

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia House. Whenever the British

Speaker: NA
Text: Government establishes an office of any

Speaker: NA
Text: kind in Australia the largest percentage

Speaker: NA
Text: of the staff is English. I ascertained

Speaker: NA
Text: when I asked the series of questions to

Speaker: NA
Text: which I have already referred, that 100

Speaker: NA
Text: typists were employed at Australia House.

Speaker: NA
Text: They were described as clerks and typists.

Speaker: NA
Text: In this Parliament House, which is the

Speaker: NA
Text: home of the Commonwealth Government,

Speaker: NA
Text: and in which all our laws are made, we

Speaker: NA
Text: have only fourteen typists. Why then,

Speaker: NA
Text: should there be 100 at Australia House?

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: man, the former member for Beid,

Speaker: NA
Text: made a valuable report on the expenditure

Speaker: NA
Text: at Australia House, and recommended

Speaker: NA
Text: many economies; but I think the office

Speaker: NA
Text: should be closed and the building sold.

Speaker: NA
Text: I f that were done an end would be put

Speaker: NA
Text: to a lot of humbug and nonsense. I n these

Speaker: NA
Text: clays it would be possible for us to have

Speaker: NA
Text: a representative in London in a modest

Speaker: NA
Text: office, and the members of the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment could, i f they so desired, talk to him

Speaker: NA
Text: by telephone almost as easily as they can

Speaker: NA
Text: talk by telephone to officers at Civic

Speaker: NA
Text: Centre. There is no need for us to con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tinue spending large sums of money on

Speaker: NA
Text: this office. I believe we should do better

Speaker: NA
Text: from a commercial point of view i f we

Speaker: NA
Text: empowered the Government to grant tra-

Speaker: NA
Text: velling expenses to bona fide commercial

Speaker: NA
Text: travellers sent to England to represent

Speaker: NA
Text: specific interests. Arrangements might

Speaker: NA
Text: possibly be made for such persons to be

Speaker: NA
Text: allowed a certain percentage on the

Speaker: NA
Text: increased sales pf Australian products in

Speaker: NA
Text: England, as shown by customs house

Speaker: NA
Text: figures, following their various appoint-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honorable member for Balaclava

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr White) had something to say, and

Speaker: NA
Text: I fear in a derogatory way, about profes-

Speaker: NA
Text: sional politicians. As a matter of fact,

Speaker: NA
Text: the right honorable member for Flinders

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Bruce) has always been quoted by

Speaker: NA
Text: me as a politician who, immediately he

Speaker: NA
Text: assumed government office, resigned from

Speaker: NA
Text: the directorate of his firm so that he could

Speaker: NA
Text: devote the whole of his time to his politi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cal duties. A ll honour to him for so

Speaker: NA
Text: doing. I make these remarks in reply to

Speaker: NA
Text: the unkind criticism of the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Balaclava.

Speaker: NA
Text: I wish, also, to say a few words in

Speaker: NA
Text: reply to the observations of the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: about the " paltry salary." I n doing so,

Speaker: NA
Text: I shall refer to Switzerland, the only real

Speaker: NA
Text: democracy in the world. I n Switzerland,

Speaker: NA
Text: the people control the parliament, not only

Speaker: NA
Text: on election day, but on every day in the

Speaker: NA
Text: year. The Swiss people had a great com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pliment paid to them when, with only the

Speaker: NA
Text: reversal of the colours, their flag was

Speaker: NA
Text: adopted as the red cross emblem. On one

Speaker: NA
Text: occasion the Government decided to

Speaker: NA
Text: appoint a Swiss as a kind of com-

Speaker: NA
Text: missionerin the United States of

Speaker: NA
Text: America. The officer appointed was to,

Speaker: NA
Text: as it were, sit astride the two continents.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Federal Government fixed the re-

Speaker: NA
Text: muneration of the office at £400.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Swiss parliament always fixes a

Speaker: NA
Text: specific sum when making such ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: pointments, and there are no additions

Speaker: NA
Text: to it. The officer, in this case, was to use

Speaker: NA
Text: the consular offices in America. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Swiss people were not consulted about the

Speaker: NA
Text: appointment, and were so incensed at the

Speaker: NA
Text: action of the Government that an initia-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive petition was circulated, with the

Speaker: NA
Text: result that the Government had to cancel

Speaker: NA
Text: the appointment.

Speaker: NA
Text: Sitting suspended from 6.15 to 8 p.m.

Speaker: Dr MALONEY
Text: I say, with all

Speaker: NA
Text: reverence, that God never created any-

Speaker: NA
Text: thing His equal or His superior. Why,

Speaker: NA
Text: then, should the electors, who are the

Speaker: NA
Text: creators of - Parliament, once in every

Speaker: NA
Text: three years, allow ^the created Parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: -to make, itself more powerful than

Speaker: NA
Text: the electors? I f the people of Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia really had the power to control

Speaker: NA
Text: the Parliament that they have created

Speaker: NA
Text: they would not allow the payment of

Speaker: NA
Text: salaries up to £5,000 a year. I t is ridicusecondary

Speaker: NA
Text: lous, in view of our limited population,

Speaker: NA
Text: to countenance, any longer, the main-

Speaker: NA
Text: tenance of an excrescence like Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: House, costing as it did over £1,000,000,

Speaker: NA
Text: including the land on which it'stands, and

Speaker: NA
Text: a further £1,000,000 for other costs. This

Speaker: NA
Text: is unjust to the people who elected.us, and

Speaker: NA
Text: it is not true democracy. I have always

Speaker: NA
Text: held that the law-maker fills the most

Speaker: NA
Text: important position to which man can

Speaker: NA
Text: aspire. Any man who gains the suffrages

Speaker: NA
Text: of his fellow citizens to become a member

Speaker: NA
Text: of Parliament, and therefore, a law-

Speaker: NA
Text: maker, should receive the highest salary

Speaker: NA
Text: that is paid in the State, excepting per-

Speaker: NA
Text: haps that paid to scientists aud experts

Speaker: NA
Text: who are invited from time to time to

Speaker: NA
Text: report upon our railways and other

Speaker: NA
Text: institutions. For 50 years in and out of

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament, and for 43 years in Parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, I have endeavoured to make the

Speaker: NA
Text: people the controlling power in the

Speaker: NA
Text: country. Until that has been done this

Speaker: NA
Text: will not be a true democracy, for the

Speaker: NA
Text: created thing has more power than its

Speaker: NA
Text: creator.

Speaker: NA
Text: Honorable members are doing a disservice

Speaker: NA
Text: to their country in delaying the passage

Speaker: NA
Text: of the measure. I rise to reply to some

Speaker: NA
Text: statements which, i f left unchallenged,

Speaker: NA
Text: would convey an erroneous impression

Speaker: NA
Text: concerning one who is not present to reply

Speaker: NA
Text: to them, a gentleman who has always

Speaker: NA
Text: manifested a very high sense of national

Speaker: NA
Text: duty, and' at the moment is on .the other

Speaker: NA
Text: side of the world in furtherance, of the

Speaker: NA
Text: interests of his country, the right honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Flinders ( Mr Bruce).

Speaker: NA
Text: The honorable member for Darling

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Blakeley) declared that he was not

Speaker: NA
Text: going to indulge in a personal attack

Speaker: NA
Text: upon the right honorable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Flinders-an d promptly proceeded to do

Speaker: NA
Text: so. I n attempting to belittle the adminis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tration of the right honorable gentleman,

Speaker: NA
Text: he alleged that Mr Bruce had worked

Speaker: NA
Text: to the detriment of our secondary, and in

Speaker: NA
Text: favour of our importing industries. I

Speaker: NA
Text: find, on examining the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: Year-Booh, that the contrary is the case.

Speaker: NA
Text: During the regime of the Bruce-Page

Speaker: NA
Text: Government there was a rather large in-

Speaker: NA
Text: crease in the number of factories in Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia and a noticeable increase in the

Speaker: NA
Text: number of persons engaged in our

Speaker: NA
Text: industries. My investigations

Speaker: NA
Text: also make it apparent that, despite the

Speaker: NA
Text: protestations of honorable members

Speaker: NA
Text: opposite, the number of factories declined

Speaker: NA
Text: somewhat, and the number pf employees

Speaker: NA
Text: in secondary industries declined consider-

Speaker: NA
Text: ably during the period that the Scullin

Speaker: NA
Text: Government was in office, and that despite

Speaker: NA
Text: the huge array of tariff schedules intro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duced by that administration.

Speaker: NA
Text: An attack was also made upon the

Speaker: NA
Text: borrowing policy of the"Bruce-Page Go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment. Every honorable member

Speaker: NA
Text: knows perfectly well that the great in-

Speaker: NA
Text: crease in borrowing that took place in the

Speaker: NA
Text: six or seven years during which that

Speaker: NA
Text: Government was in power was chiefly on

Speaker: NA
Text: behalf of the States, not of the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth. I t was largely because of the

Speaker: NA
Text: endeavours of the right honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber for Flinders, in collaboration with

Speaker: NA
Text: the right honorable member for Cowper

Speaker: NA
Text: (Dr Earle Page),.that the Loan Council

Speaker: NA
Text: came into being. That body had the

Speaker: NA
Text: effect of steadying Australia's borrowing,

Speaker: NA
Text: and of making it possible to obtain loans

Speaker: NA
Text: on better terms. Certainly it has stood

Speaker: NA
Text: as a bulwark of safety during the rather

Speaker: NA
Text: disastrous period through which we are

Speaker: NA
Text: passing.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honorable member for Darling

Speaker: NA
Text: stated that the right honorable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Flinders is a person devoid of Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian sentiment. There are two classes

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australians, those whose outlook is

Speaker: NA
Text: bounded by our shores, and those who

Speaker: NA
Text: realize that the security and safety of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commonwealth are bound up with

Speaker: NA
Text: Imperial relations, and a sound inter-

Speaker: NA
Text: national outlook. If the sneer

Speaker: NA
Text: of the honorable member for Darling

Speaker: NA
Text: places the right honorable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Flinders in the second category, it

Speaker: NA
Text: becomes a high compliment.

Speaker: NA
Text: The same honorable member insinuated

Speaker: NA
Text: that the right honorable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Flinders is not temperamentally fitted for

Speaker: NA
Text: the task that he has undertaken. All who

Speaker: NA
Text: know the right honorable gentleman

Speaker: NA
Text: would scout the suggestion that he is tem-

Speaker: NA
Text: peramentally unbalanced, incautious, apt

Speaker: NA
Text: to be swayed by illogical contentions, or

Speaker: NA
Text: by sentimental appeals. Honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers who cannot do better than make

Speaker: NA
Text: such ludicrous attacks upon a person

Speaker: NA
Text: noted for his logic and imperturbability

Speaker: NA
Text: should remain silent.

Speaker: NA
Text: Then the accusation was levelled at the

Speaker: NA
Text: right honorable member that, while over-

Speaker: NA
Text: seas, he will sacrifice the interests of

Speaker: NA
Text: nation to his personal advantage. The

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member who made that accusa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion should feel ashamed.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honorable member for Hunter

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr James) declared that, the right hon-

Speaker: NA
Text: orable member for Flinders obtained the

Speaker: NA
Text: bulk of his education abroad, aud con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sidered himself so superior to the people

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australia that, when the war broke out

Speaker: NA
Text: he enlisted in Great Britain. Those who

Speaker: NA
Text: are familiar with the right honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: gentleman's history are aware that he had

Speaker: NA
Text: a splendid athletic and scholastic career

Speaker: NA
Text: in one of Melbourne's public schools. On

Speaker: NA
Text: the second point I may say that instead of

Speaker: NA
Text: returning to Australia to enlist, and so

Speaker: NA
Text: wasting time, the right honorable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Flinders, being in. England at the

Speaker: NA
Text: time, seized the earliest opportunity to

Speaker: NA
Text: enlist, so that he might give his services

Speaker: NA
Text: during the dark days of 1914-18, au ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: ample which might well have been fol-

Speaker: NA
Text: lowed by a goodly number of honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: members on the other side of the House-

Speaker: NA
Text: Very few members of this House, I am

Speaker: NA
Text: sure, really believe that the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: could have appointed any one else who

Speaker: NA
Text: would perform this work as satisfactorily

Speaker: NA
Text: as Mr Bruce could do. For once, I

Speaker: NA
Text: shall venture to assume the role of. pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: phet. I am quite certain that after he

Speaker: NA
Text: has accomplished his mission, and per-

Speaker: NA
Text: formed a great national service for Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia, Mr Bruce will return, with his

Speaker: NA
Text: reputation enhanced both at home and

Speaker: NA
Text: abroad.

Text: New England) to

Text: [8.16] -I t seems to me that the real

Text: nose of this bill is being clouded by

Text: persona] attack directed by members

Text: the Opposition against the right honorMinisters.

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Flinders ( Mr Bruce).

Speaker: NA
Text: T exonerate the right honorahle the

Speaker: NA
Text: Loader of the Opposition ( Mr Scullin),

Speaker: NA
Text: whose remarks were very fair, and

Speaker: NA
Text: that critical nature which we hayc come

Speaker: NA
Text: to expect from him. One can only conthe

Speaker: NA
Text: clude, after hearing the speeches of some

Speaker: NA
Text: of his colleagues, however, that they

Text: been waiting for the opportunity to throw

Text: mud at the right honorable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Flindevs.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr BEASLEY/ -O f course, the right

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member never threw any mud

Text: himself.'

Speaker: Mr THOMPSON
Text: No , I do not

Speaker: NA
Text: the think he ever did. This personal attack

Text: by honorable members who are opposing

Text: the bill has completely vitiated their

Text: arguments. Their criticism is clearly

Text: inspired by personal malice of a type

Text: that is seldom seen in this House, and

Text: which I myself have never witnessed here

Text: before.

Speaker: Mr WARD
Text: Tha t is a great pity!

Speaker: Mr THOMPSON
Text: Yes , it is, and I

Speaker: NA
Text: may add that it is only since the advent

Speaker: NA
Text: of the honorable member for East Syd-

Speaker: NA
Text: ney ( Mr Ward), and his colleagues in

Speaker: NA
Text: this House, that we have got down to the

Speaker: NA
Text: low level-almos t to the gutter level, I

Speaker: NA
Text: might say-tha t characterizes on some

Speaker: NA
Text: occasions, the proceedings of the Parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of Now South Wales.

Speaker: NA
Text: This bill introduces a new principle.'

Speaker: NA
Text: The propositi to send a Resident Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: to London has been discussed before, but

Speaker: NA
Text: it has always been regarded as imprac-

Speaker: NA
Text: ticable. I wtis surprised, therefore, to

Speaker: NA
Text: learn that the matter had been revived by

Speaker: NA
Text: this Government, and that it was pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: posed to appoint such a Minister. I

Speaker: NA
Text: like to see new ideas introduced-w e do

Speaker: NA
Text: not have enough of them in Australia-

Speaker: NA
Text: and i f this is going to be an improvement

Speaker: NA
Text: on the ghastly failure of the high com-

Speaker: NA
Text: tnissionership during the last fifteen

Speaker: NA
Text: years, it is to be welcomed. I am sure

Speaker: NA
Text: that the great majority of the citizens of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia have been bitterly disappointed

Speaker: NA
Text: at the results achieved by the High Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: missioners iri London. This is not due

Speaker: NA
Text: the calibre of the men who have repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: pursented us abroad, although it is true, as

Speaker: NA
Text: a somebody has said, that they have gener-

Speaker: NA
Text: of ally been discarded politicians or ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: The office has been dragged

Speaker: NA
Text: down to the level of a mere political job,

Speaker: NA
Text: to be offered to some individual who has

Speaker: NA
Text: hecome, for the moment, inconvenient.

Speaker: NA
Text: of No fault could be found with some of

Speaker: NA
Text: the men who have filled this position i n

Speaker: NA
Text: past. Such men as Sir George Beid

Speaker: NA
Text: and Sir Joseph Cook rendered good ser-

Speaker: NA
Text: have vice to their country, and the recent

Speaker: NA
Text: occupant of the position, Sir Granville

Speaker: NA
Text: Ryrie, has filled i t worthily, considering

Speaker: NA
Text: his own confession that he was not used

Speaker: NA
Text: to that kind of work. A t any rate, he

Speaker: NA
Text: has maintained the prestige of Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: The point at issue i n connexion with

Speaker: NA
Text: this proposal is not the merits or de-

Speaker: NA
Text: merits of the right honorable member f or

Speaker: NA
Text: Flinders. We who have known the right

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable gentleman, and have seen his

Speaker: NA
Text: work as Prime Minister, regard him as

Speaker: NA
Text: the outstanding man f or a position

Speaker: NA
Text: such as this. We have no doubt that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government has chosen wisely. Never-

Speaker: NA
Text: theless, this appointment represents a

Speaker: NA
Text: new departure i n Australian politics, and

Speaker: NA
Text: I should be surprised i f i t turns out to

Speaker: NA
Text: be more thana temporary experiment.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am not hostile to the Government on

Speaker: NA
Text: this issue, but I remind honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers that a condition upon which mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers are elected to this Parliament is

Speaker: NA
Text: that they remain in Australia and per-

Speaker: NA
Text: sonally attend to the needs of their con-

Speaker: NA
Text: stituents. I t is obvious that i f the right

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member f o r Flinders, useful as

Speaker: NA
Text: he may be to Australia while abroad, is

Speaker: NA
Text: to remain i n London f or two years, he

Speaker: NA
Text: w i l l not be able to represent the people

Speaker: NA
Text: of Flinders i n this House. I t may be

Speaker: NA
Text: that the electors of Flinders are suffi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ciently patriotic, or will be so nattered at

Speaker: NA
Text: his having been picked on f or this experi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, that they w i l l be quite" satisfied to

Speaker: NA
Text: allow their representative to go abroad

Speaker: NA
Text: practically f o r the whole term of Parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, and, i f so. i t shows that they have

Speaker: NA
Text: been able to take a larger view of the

Speaker: NA
Text: matter than we may expect the electors

Speaker: NA
Text: of most constituencies to do.

Speaker: Mr MAXWELL
Text: The y have their

Speaker: NA
Text: remedy i n their own hands.

Speaker: Mr THOMPSON
Text: Y e s ; but is

Speaker: NA
Text: f a i r to put any electorate i n the position

Speaker: NA
Text: of having to take i t or leave it? Is i t

Speaker: NA
Text: f a i r to say to the electors of Flinders, or

Speaker: NA
Text: any other constituency, " This is the man

Speaker: NA
Text: we have selected to send abroad. He

Speaker: NA
Text: is going to London as our ambassador

Speaker: NA
Text: for two years, and we are handing over

Speaker: NA
Text: to one of his colleagues the task of repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: senting you as well as his own con-

Speaker: NA
Text: stituents ". I am assuming that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government has not taken any steps-to

Speaker: NA
Text: find out whether the electors of Flinders

Speaker: NA
Text: are agreeable to this most radical change.

Speaker: NA
Text: I presume that, the prestige of Mr Bruce

Speaker: NA
Text: is so high to-day that the great majority

Speaker: NA
Text: of his electors are prepared to subscribe

Speaker: NA
Text: to that change; but does not that of itself

Speaker: NA
Text: indicate that the Government is able to

Speaker: NA
Text: do this only because of his high prestige

Speaker: NA
Text: and outstanding personality. No other

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate would subscribe to the arrange-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment f o r a moment. I f a man who was

Speaker: NA
Text: standing f o r Parliament were to tell the

Speaker: NA
Text: electors that, i f elected, he had a chance

Speaker: NA
Text: of going abroad as ambassador f or two

Speaker: NA
Text: years, I feel sure that he would not have

Speaker: NA
Text: a chance of being returned. I t is evi-

Speaker: NA
Text: dent, therefore, that the Government is

Speaker: NA
Text: merely making use of the services of Mr .

Speaker: NA
Text: Bruce while they are available, and is not

Speaker: NA
Text: contemplating making this f o r m of repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sentation a permanent one. Therefore,

Speaker: NA
Text: in my opinion, the position could have

Speaker: NA
Text: been met without introducing this bill,

Speaker: NA
Text: merely by allowing Mr Bruce to go

Text: to London f o i ' six or twelve months in

Text: order to carry through tlie necessary

Speaker: NA
Text: financial operations. I t would only be

Speaker: NA
Text: necessary to announce to the people that,

Speaker: NA
Text: in due course, he would be returning to

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, and that the position of H i g h

Speaker: NA
Text: Commissioner would then be recon-

Speaker: NA
Text: sidered.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is no doubt that the High Coni-

Speaker: NA
Text: missionership will have to be reviewed

Speaker: NA
Text: in the near future. Some honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: members have referred to the high cost of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia House, and have questioned

Speaker: NA
Text: the actual value of the H i g h Commis-

Speaker: NA
Text: sionership to Australia. I t is extra-

Speaker: NA
Text: ordinary that, although originally the

Speaker: NA
Text: High Commissioner was supposed to per-

Speaker: NA
Text: form' all the functions of a Besident

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister, and almost those of an

Speaker: NA
Text: ambassador, i n London, he has never

Speaker: NA
Text: actually done anything of the kind. We

Speaker: NA
Text: have always had the spectacle of a stream

Speaker: NA
Text: i t of Ministers going to London on one

Speaker: NA
Text: pretext or another. The last Government

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot dispute that, because i t sent as

Speaker: NA
Text: many of its members abroad as did any

Speaker: NA
Text: other government. Indeed, on one

Speaker: NA
Text: occasion, i t sent nearly half the Ministry.

Speaker: Mr GARDNER
Text: Onl y four Ministers.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr THOMPSON ' - I stand cor-

Speaker: NA
Text: rected; i t sent only four. This sending

Speaker: NA
Text: of Ministers abroad has proved of how

Speaker: NA
Text: little use the H i g h Commissionership

Speaker: NA
Text: has been to Australia. On the financial

Speaker: NA
Text: side, also, i t has failed us. A little while

Speaker: NA
Text: ago we found i t necessary to send a

Speaker: NA
Text: high Treasury official, Mr Collins,

Speaker: NA
Text: abroad., as our financial adviser, and f o r

Speaker: NA
Text: the last twelve months he has been vir-

Speaker: NA
Text: tually i n charge of Australia House.

Speaker: NA
Text: The position of High Commissioner will

Speaker: NA
Text: shortly become vacant, and the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, I think, is wise in not following

Speaker: NA
Text: the haphazard practice of its prede-

Speaker: NA
Text: cessors in grabbing the first handy man

Speaker: NA
Text: and sending him abroad as Australia's

Speaker: NA
Text: representative. The Government has

Speaker: NA
Text: done the right thing in holding up the

Speaker: NA
Text: appointment. I feel sure that, perhaps

Speaker: NA
Text: before twelve months have gone by, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government will be forced to alter its

Speaker: NA
Text: policy of having a Resident Minister in

Speaker: NA
Text: London. 1 do not think that it will be

Speaker: NA
Text: possible or practicable for the right

Speaker: NA
Text: orable member for Flinders to stay away

Speaker: NA
Text: from Australia and continue to represent

Speaker: NA
Text: a section of the electors of the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth. On the surface the proposal

Speaker: NA
Text: is a most extraordinary one, and I

Speaker: NA
Text: think the Government will be forced to

Speaker: NA
Text: make an alteration, because the new

Speaker: NA
Text: arrangement will be found to be

Speaker: NA
Text: impracticable. I n the meantime, there

Speaker: NA
Text: is no High Commissioner in Lon-

Speaker: NA
Text: don, and we must have some one

Speaker: NA
Text: there with the necessary status and

Speaker: NA
Text: authority to handle the gigantic financial

Speaker: NA
Text: operations now crowding on us. The

Speaker: NA
Text: right honorable member for Flinders

Speaker: NA
Text: understands high finance, and can

Speaker: NA
Text: handle big operations, and as a

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister he will have the necessary

Speaker: NA
Text: prestige to move effectively in London

Speaker: NA
Text: financial circles. I disregard the sugges-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion that the position will be merely a

Speaker: NA
Text: social one.; but a country's ambassador

Speaker: NA
Text: must have social prestige, and the right

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member for Flinders will

Speaker: NA
Text: represent Australia with dignity. He

Speaker: NA
Text: will certainly create a favorable im-

Speaker: NA
Text: pression on the other side of the world.

Speaker: NA
Text: He has been attacked on the ground of

Speaker: NA
Text: his alleged financial incompetency and

Speaker: NA
Text: the record of the Bruce-Page Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment has been cited, mostly by persons

Speaker: NA
Text: who were not in this Parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: when it was in power, and are mere

Speaker: NA
Text: newcomers to politics. I venture to

Speaker: NA
Text: say that the most vitriolic of the

Speaker: NA
Text: clitics of the right honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber for Flinders have not taken the

Speaker: NA
Text: trouble to look up the figures of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Bruce-Page regime. They are figures

Speaker: NA
Text: whose accuracy cannot be challenged. I n

Speaker: NA
Text: -its six and a half years of office, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Bruce-Page Government borrowed

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Order !

Speaker: Mr THOMPSON
Text: I t has been

Speaker: NA
Text: claimed that the qualifications of the

Speaker: NA
Text: right honorable member for Flinders are

Speaker: NA
Text: vitiated by the financial record of his

Speaker: NA
Text: government, and I want, briefly, to indi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cate the merits of the financial adminis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tration of that Government to show why

Speaker: NA
Text: we have so much faith in this particular

Speaker: NA
Text: appointment. One of the outstanding

Speaker: NA
Text: qualifications of the right honorable mem- -

Speaker: NA
Text: ber is the great success with which he

Speaker: NA
Text: handled the financial problems of Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: hon- tralia. A great deal has been said about

Speaker: NA
Text: the tremendous borrowings of the Bruce-

Speaker: NA
Text: Page Government, and about its extrava-

Speaker: NA
Text: gance. As a matter of fact, in the six

Speaker: NA
Text: and a half years it was forced to borrow

Speaker: NA
Text: £207,000,000 on behalf of the States.

Speaker: NA
Text: Members of the Labour party in the

Speaker: NA
Text: State Parliaments were just as insistent

Speaker: NA
Text: as other parties in forcing the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth to borrow on their behalf, so that

Speaker: NA
Text: money could be spent on State public

Speaker: NA
Text: works.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Order ! I f I were

Speaker: NA
Text: to permit the honorable member to ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: duce many more figures relating to the

Speaker: NA
Text: financial administration of the Bruce-

Speaker: NA
Text: Page Government, I might just as well

Speaker: NA
Text: allow him to traverse the whole of the

Speaker: NA
Text: record of that Government. Honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: members will admit that they have been

Speaker: NA
Text: given .great latitude during this debate,

Speaker: NA
Text: but I must now insist on some attempt

Speaker: NA
Text: being made to connect remarks with the

Speaker: NA
Text: bill.

Speaker: Mr THOMPSON
Text: I A accept your

Speaker: NA
Text: correction, Mr Speaker, but some hon-

Speaker: NA
Text: orable members, having already cited

Speaker: NA
Text: figures, I thought it proper to reply to

Speaker: NA
Text: them. Briefly, I may say, that the Bruce-

Speaker: NA
Text: Page Government established sinking

Speaker: NA
Text: funds which reduced the war debt by

Speaker: NA
Text: £45,000,000. That was done under the

Speaker: NA
Text: leadership of a gentleman who, some

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable members say, has not the capa-

Speaker: NA
Text: city to be a Besident Minister in London

Speaker: NA
Text: or to carry out important financial trans-

Speaker: NA
Text: actions. The record of the Bruce-Page

Speaker: NA
Text: Government stands for itself. I t is true

Speaker: NA
Text: that there was a lot of money to spend,

Speaker: NA
Text: and that the right honorable member

Speaker: NA
Text: spent i t like a gentleman, but during the

Speaker: NA
Text: whole of that time there was an insis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tent demand from all quarters that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth Government should spend

Speaker: NA
Text: every penny it could lay its hands on.

Speaker: NA
Text: I n those years, the Government which did

Speaker: NA
Text: not borrow at the rate of £40,000,000 a

Speaker: NA
Text: year was regarded as a " d u d " ; as one

Speaker: NA
Text: that was not doing its job. I t is of no

Speaker: NA
Text: use saying now that the happenings

Speaker: NA
Text: of that period were evidence of the

Speaker: NA
Text: incapacity of the right honorable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Flinders, or that he was the most

Speaker: NA
Text: disastrous Prime Minister whom Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia has ever had, and certainly

Speaker: NA
Text: the worst man we could send to

Speaker: NA
Text: London to handle important conver-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion operations. For these reasons,

Speaker: NA
Text: apart from the point 1 have raised,

Speaker: NA
Text: that it is very doubtful whether

Speaker: NA
Text: the electors of Flinders are getting a fair

Speaker: NA
Text: deal, I cannot find fault with the present

Speaker: NA
Text: proposal. So far as the personality of

Speaker: NA
Text: the man chosen is concerned, the case is

Speaker: NA
Text: complete. I think that 90 per cent, of

Speaker: NA
Text: - the people of Australia, even the sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: porters of the vociferous party opposing

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government, if asked their opinion,

Speaker: NA
Text: would say that they have per-

Speaker: NA
Text: fect faith in - the ability

Speaker: NA
Text: the right honorable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Flinders to represent Australia in these

Speaker: NA
Text: important financial transactions abroad.

Speaker: Mr WARD
Text: East Sydney) [8.40] -

Speaker: NA
Text: The whole of the debate seems to have

Speaker: NA
Text: centred upon the gentleman chosen

Speaker: NA
Text: as Resident Minister in London, and very

Speaker: NA
Text: little reason has been shown by sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: porters of the Government why any one

Speaker: NA
Text: should be sent to the other side of the

Speaker: NA
Text: world as Resident Minister. I have

Speaker: NA
Text: heard it suggested that one reason why

Speaker: NA
Text: the right honorable member for Flinders

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Bruce) has been chosen is that he

Speaker: NA
Text: was not prepared to take a subordinate

Speaker: NA
Text: post in this Cabinet as a Minister without

Speaker: NA
Text: Portfolio, and thought that it would

Speaker: NA
Text: probably sound much better i f his title

Speaker: NA
Text: were Resident Minister in London; and

Speaker: NA
Text: that i f a conversion loan is successfully

Speaker: NA
Text: floated he will return to take up the posi- of the bill.

Speaker: NA
Text: tion he has occupied since the general

Speaker: NA
Text: election, although not nominally-tha t of

Speaker: NA
Text: leader of the Government and Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am not satisfied that the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: has given us the full reasons why the

Speaker: NA
Text: right honorable member for Flinders has

Speaker: NA
Text: been sent to the other side of the world.

Speaker: NA
Text: With all due respect to those who say that

Speaker: NA
Text: the negotiations at Ottawa were carried

Speaker: NA
Text: out satisfactorily so far as Australia is

Speaker: NA
Text: concerned, I beg to differ from them. I

Speaker: NA
Text: say that the interests of Australia were

Speaker: NA
Text: sacrificed, and the people of this country

Speaker: NA
Text: will realize that in the near future. We

Speaker: NA
Text: find, on reading the press reports, which

Speaker: NA
Text: the Prime Minister says are substantially

Speaker: NA
Text: correct, that-

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia undertakes that protection by

Speaker: NA
Text: tariffs shall be afforded only to those indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tries wliich are reasonably assured of a sound

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity for success, and undertakes also

Speaker: NA
Text: that during the currency of the agreement

Speaker: NA
Text: the tariff shall be based on the principle that

Speaker: NA
Text: the protective duties shall not exceed such a

Speaker: NA
Text: levdl as will give British producers the full

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity for reasonable competition on the

Speaker: NA
Text: basis of the relative cost of economical and

Speaker: NA
Text: efficient production.

Speaker: NA
Text: Who is to determine this ? I n my opinion

Speaker: NA
Text: the right honorable member for Flinders

Speaker: NA
Text: is transferring the seat of Government of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commonwealth to the other side of

Speaker: NA
Text: the world. From London he will indicate

Speaker: NA
Text: which Australian industries the British

Speaker: NA
Text: capitalists think should be sacrificed. He

Speaker: NA
Text: is certainly qualified to undertake

Speaker: NA
Text: of that task. .So far as his Australian out-

Speaker: NA
Text: look is concerned, all that we can

Speaker: NA
Text: say about him is that it was the

Speaker: NA
Text: misfortune of Australia that he was born

Speaker: NA
Text: in this country. I t is all eyewash for the

Speaker: NA
Text: right honorable member for Cowper (Dr

Speaker: NA
Text: Earle Page) to try to justify this

Speaker: NA
Text: appointment by saying that it is very

Speaker: NA
Text: necessary that members of this Parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment should have a knowledge of foreign

Speaker: NA
Text: affairs and international events, while a

Speaker: NA
Text: film depicting development in another

Speaker: NA
Text: part of the world is not permitted to he

Speaker: NA
Text: screened in Australia.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Order !

Speaker: Mr WARD
Text: Othe r honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: I t is not a question

Speaker: NA
Text: of what other honorahle members have

Speaker: NA
Text: said; the Chair must insist on the strict

Speaker: NA
Text: relevancy of the debate to the provisions

Speaker: Mr WARD
Text: Th e honorable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Balaclava spoke of professional poli-

Speaker: NA
Text: ticians; of men unsuccessful in other

Speaker: NA
Text: callings, but having the gift of the gab,

Speaker: NA
Text: being able to secure positions in Parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. I n reply to him, I say

Speaker: NA
Text: that the man who has no outside ties

Speaker: NA
Text: can speak his mind in this chamber; but

Speaker: NA
Text: the man with outside interests is inclined-

Speaker: NA
Text: to let his judgment be dictated by those

Speaker: NA
Text: interests. The right honorable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Flinders will not only find his task

Speaker: NA
Text: in London a pleasing one, but will also

Speaker: NA
Text: be.serving his own interests as a member

Speaker: NA
Text: of a big importing firm which is not

Speaker: NA
Text: favorably disposed towards the build-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing up of Australian industries.

Speaker: NA
Text: The right houorable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Cowper (Dr Earle Page) remarked

Speaker: NA
Text: that it would not matter if no

Speaker: NA
Text: saving were being made as the

Speaker: NA
Text: result of the Government's proposal.

Speaker: NA
Text: Of course, in dealing with the appoint-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment as Resident Minister in Loudon of

Speaker: NA
Text: a member to whom honorable members

Speaker: NA
Text: opposite, and in the Country party, look

Speaker: NA
Text: with reverence, thousands of pounds can

Speaker: NA
Text: be spent without comment; but within

Speaker: NA
Text: a few days, when supporters of the Go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment will be dealing with invalid

Speaker: NA
Text: and old-age pensions, they will consider

Speaker: NA
Text: every penny! We are told that the

Speaker: NA
Text: palatial qnarter3 provided for the High

Speaker: NA
Text: Commissioner in London are not suffi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cient to hoii3C the right honorable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Flinders. What are his special quali-

Speaker: NA
Text: fications, of which so much has been said

Speaker: NA
Text: to-day? I f we require a representative

Speaker: NA
Text: in London merely to wear a top bat at the

Speaker: NA
Text: right angle, or look well in spats, no doubt

Speaker: NA
Text: the right man has been chosen for the

Speaker: NA
Text: position. I understood that we were to

Speaker: NA
Text: hear some useful remarks from the

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member for Corio ( Mr Casey),

Speaker: NA
Text: but despite his experience on the other

Speaker: NA
Text: side of the'world, the only contribution

Speaker: NA
Text: that he made to this debate was an objec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion to the insinuation that the right

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member for Flinders was not

Speaker: NA
Text: a suitable person to represent Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: abroad. I make no apology for what 1

Speaker: NA
Text: have said concerning the right honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member. He has not an Australian out-

Speaker: NA
Text: look, and he cannot possibly look after

Speaker: NA
Text: the interests of the people of this country

Speaker: NA
Text: in a proper manner. I f the desire was to

Speaker: NA
Text: appoint a British Imperialist to repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sent us in London, the right man has been

Speaker: NA
Text: chosen. He will make a. good represen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tative of Britain, but a poor one of Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia. The object of the Ottawa Con-

Speaker: NA
Text: ference was to organize the British Em-

Speaker: NA
Text: pire as a solid economic unit, so that it

Speaker: NA
Text: would be in a favorable position to

Speaker: NA
Text: compete with other similar combinations

Speaker: NA
Text: of peoples, including those of the

Speaker: NA
Text: United States of America; which are

Speaker: NA
Text: making inroads upon the British

Speaker: NA
Text: markets. Great Britain does not

Speaker: NA
Text: desire the secondary industries of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia to be built up. I t wishes to

Speaker: NA
Text: see them sacrificed, and desires that we

Speaker: NA
Text: shall confine our attention to the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duction of the raw materials required in

Speaker: NA
Text: factories overseas.

Speaker: NA
Text: I remember, a few months ago, the Go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment and its supporters scoffing at

Speaker: NA
Text: certain suggestions put forward by my

Speaker: NA
Text: party for the conversion of loans at re-

Speaker: NA
Text: duced rates of interest. That policy was

Speaker: NA
Text: said to be one of repudiation. I t was

Speaker: NA
Text: declared that my party was proceeding

Speaker: NA
Text: on wrong lines, and that there should be

Speaker: NA
Text: no compulsory conversion of loans. When

Speaker: NA
Text: the party opposite, in conjunction with

Speaker: NA
Text: the then government, appealed to the pub-

Speaker: NA
Text: lic for the conversion of internal loans, it

Speaker: NA
Text: promised that compulsion would not be

Speaker: NA
Text: applied; but the Government said to the

Speaker: NA
Text: bondholders: " We shall give you until a

Speaker: NA
Text: certain' date to convert voluntarily, and

Speaker: NA
Text: after that you will have to convert". Let

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government lay its cards on the table,

Speaker: NA
Text: and say frankly why the right honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Flinders is being sent abroad.

Speaker: NA
Text: It should let the people know that Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia's interests are being sacrificed. The

Speaker: NA
Text: people will realize that, in any event, a

Speaker: NA
Text: few months hence. Many members op-

Speaker: NA
Text: posite will in all probability be remem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bered solely as one-Parliament members.

Speaker: NA
Text: .Their return at the last election was due

Speaker: NA
Text: to the fact that on that occasion the elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tors suffered from a form of temporary

Speaker: NA
Text: insanity. The sooner the people have

Speaker: NA
Text: an opportunity to return to power a go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment with a truly Australian outlook

Speaker: NA
Text: to correct the wrongs committed by the

Speaker: NA
Text: present anti-Australian Government

Speaker: NA
Text: represented on the other side of the

Speaker: NA
Text: world by an anti-Australian Resident

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Th e honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber may not apply the term " anti-Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia]! " to a member of this House. I

Speaker: NA
Text: ask him to withdraw the expression.

Speaker: Mr WARD
Text: I withdraw it. I f a

Speaker: NA
Text: revulsion of feeling has not already

Speaker: NA
Text: occurred throughout the Commonwealth,

Speaker: NA
Text: public opinion will inevitably swing

Speaker: NA
Text: against the Government a.t no distant

Speaker: NA
Text: date, and an opportunity will then be

Speaker: NA
Text: afforded to put into operation a true Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian policy. I f the qualifications of

Speaker: NA
Text: the right honorable member for Flinders

Speaker: NA
Text: are beyond question, why this spirited

Speaker: NA
Text: defence of them? Many supporters of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government 'have rushed to his

Speaker: NA
Text: defence.

Speaker: Mr WHITE
Text: Becaus e he is absent.

Speaker: Mr WARD
Text: Th e right honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member had not to wait until he left

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia to know what my party thought

Speaker: NA
Text: of him. I realize that the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: has the necessary number of supporters

Speaker: NA
Text: in this House to enable it to pass this

Speaker: NA
Text: bill, and to retain the right honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member as Resident Minister in London

Speaker: NA
Text: for as long a term as i t will

Speaker: NA
Text: remain in . office; but honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: members opposite should not prate

Speaker: NA
Text: about his special qualifications. The

Speaker: NA
Text: fact cannot be disguised that he has

Speaker: NA
Text: gone to London as Resident Minister to

Speaker: NA
Text: obtain directions from the British

Speaker: NA
Text: imperialists as to certain action that shall

Speaker: NA
Text: be taken in this country, and those in-

Speaker: NA
Text: structions will be carried out to the

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government may go ahead with its

Speaker: NA
Text: policy; but the members o.f my party

Speaker: NA
Text: will tell the people the true position.

Speaker: NA
Text: Although we number only five in this

Speaker: NA
Text: House, we represent 540,000 voters in

Speaker: NA
Text: New South Wales. I f the opportunity

Speaker: NA
Text: were presented for another election, our

Speaker: NA
Text: numbers would be vastly increased, and

Speaker: NA
Text: the fact would be revealed that we now

Speaker: NA
Text: have the support of the majority of the

Speaker: NA
Text: electors in that State. When a true

Speaker: NA
Text: Labour Government is returned to this

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament, this anti-Australian bill will

Speaker: NA
Text: be repealed.

Speaker: Mr ARCHDALE PARKHILL
Text: Warhe

Speaker: NA
Text: ringah-Ministe r for the Interior) out of it.

Speaker: NA
Text: [8.54] -Thi s simple measure merely

Speaker: NA
Text: gives the right honorable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Flinders ( Mr Bruce), while in London,

Speaker: NA
Text: the powers of the' High Commissioner,

Speaker: NA
Text: and it is extraordinary that so much

Speaker: NA
Text: extraneous matter has been imported

Speaker: NA
Text: into this debate. The most bitter attacks

Speaker: NA
Text: have been made on the right honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: gentleman. Some honorable members

Speaker: NA
Text: were unfair enough to preface their

Speaker: NA
Text: remarks by stating that they did

Speaker: NA
Text: intend to be personal, and to follow

Speaker: NA
Text: that opening observation with spleto

Speaker: NA
Text: netic outbursts, because the right honto

Speaker: NA
Text: orable member, being absent, could I t

Speaker: NA
Text: not reply to them. I f he had been here,

Speaker: NA
Text: I venture to say that not one of those

Speaker: NA
Text: members would have been game to say a sioner.

Speaker: NA
Text: fraction of what they have said this after-

Speaker: NA
Text: noon and to-night. When the right

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member is in this chamber, he

Speaker: NA
Text: can well look after himself. We have

Speaker: NA
Text: listened with close attention to the state-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments that he has made on various

Speaker: NA
Text: occasions on important subjects, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: utterances of few members of this House

Speaker: NA
Text: have commanded so much respect as

Speaker: NA
Text: have those of the right honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber for Flinders on financial matters,

Speaker: NA
Text: imperial' issues, and foreign relations.

Text: of Woolloomooloo. They are not true

Text: Australian sentiments; but the honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for East Sydney knows no

Speaker: NA
Text: others. Brought up in that atmosphere,

Speaker: NA
Text: grovels in it, and he will never get

Text: The purpose of the bill is clear, and I

Speaker: NA
Text: do not intend to analyse the speeches of

Text: honorable members who have opposed it.

Text: For many years i t has been recognized

Speaker: NA

Text: this House until this afternoon that we

Speaker: NA
Text: should abolish the office of High Commis-

Text: The Leader of the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Scullin) suggested that i f he had

Text: Sydney ( Mr Ward), or, for that

Speaker: NA
Text: They represent only about 5 per cent, of

Speaker: NA
Text: in which the right honorable gentleman is .

Text: held by the people of Australia.

Text: interests of the Mother Country. The

Text: renvesentotive in Great. Britain of White

Text: TIous" does not sink his indivi-

Text: duality as an American citizen. He does

Text: of Australia should emulate in the

Text: proposal is a departure from established

Text: precedent. The honorable member for

Text: New England ( Mr Thompson) made a

Text: strong point when he urged that the

Text: electorate represented by the right hon-

Text: I orable member for Flinders had a right

Text: to be considered iu this matter. Per-

Text: sonally, I have nothing against the right

Text: honorable gentleman, but I entirely differ

Text: ber for New England that the electors

Text: concerned should have been consulted.

Text: extent, and I feel sure that had the elec-

Text: tors been told that, within a compara-

Text: tively short time of his election he would

Text: fov a. period of two years, he would not

Text: have been returned. Mr Collins, the

Text: Official Secretary of Australia House,

Text: was appointed by the Government led by

Text: the right honorable member for Flinders,

Text: and is well equipped to carry through

Text: successfully any loan conversion opera-

Text: tions that may be deemed necessary. The

Text: new Besident Minister will be obliged to

Text: wait, had he been entrusted with the

Text: mission. Some time ago, it was antici-

Text: pated that loan conversions on a large

Text: scale would take place. We were led to .

Text: believe that immediately upon his arrival

Text: in London the right honorable member

Text: for Minders would get in touch with

Text: financial interests and take steps to

Text: vert oar overseas debts into securities

Text: bearing a lower rate of interest. We are

Text: now advised that the only operation

Text: before Christmas will be the conversion

Text: of the £ 13y000,000 due by the New South

Speaker: NA
Text: Wales Government.

Text: Ther e will be another

Speaker: NA
Text: conversion next year.

Text: Neithe r the honor-

Text: able member for Flinders ( Mr Bruce)

Speaker: NA
Text: nor anybody else can foretell that next

Text: year will be more suitable than the

Text: present. He cannot do this job better

Text: as the proposed appointment involves an

Text: entirely new departure, something with-

Text: out precedent in Australia or in any

Text: other portion of the Empire, the Govern-

Text: ment will have to support it with stronger

Text: reasons than have yet been given to this

Text: House before it will be approved by the

Text: people. Even the Attorney-General ( Mr.

Text: Latham) has stated that he regards the

Speaker: NA
Text: The Leader of the Country party (Dr

Speaker: NA
Text: Earle Page) declared that he has

Speaker: NA
Text: advocated for years the appointment of

Speaker: NA
Text: a Besident Minister in London. He has

Speaker: NA
Text: also advocated for years, without result,

Text: the creation of new States, and,

Speaker: NA
Text: apparently, will continue to do. so for

Text: many more years. The right honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: gentleman is fond of chasing a will-o'-the

Speaker: NA
Text: wisp. The reasons advanced by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Attorney-General cancel the arguments

Speaker: NA
Text: adduced by other supporters of the bill.

Speaker: NA
Text: We are told that the passage of the hill

Text: is necessary in order that the right honoreverybody.

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Flinders may take con-

Speaker: NA
Text: trol of the staff at Australia House.

Speaker: NA
Text: Without this legislation he can still take

Speaker: NA
Text: charge of the staff while he is in Lon-

Speaker: NA
Text: don, but I hope he will not remain abroad

Speaker: NA
Text: for more than a few months, because the

Speaker: NA
Text: present Ministry is not over-rich in

Speaker: NA
Text: ability, and i f the right honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber for Flinders is as capable as his

Text: friends have declared during this debate,

Text: see no justification for the bill, and the

Text: reason for its introduction is a mystery.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr E. F. HARRISON (Bendigo)

Speaker: NA
Text: [9.18] -I n answering some of the critiwhich

Speaker: NA
Text: cism that has been directed by members

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Opposition against, the right hon-

Speaker: NA
Text: orable member for Flinders ( Mr Bruce),

Speaker: NA
Text: con- I do not propose to follow them to the

Speaker: NA
Text: depths to which they descended. At the

Speaker: NA
Text: outset I wish to nail the oft-repeated lie

Speaker: NA
Text: that the right honorable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Flinders was educated abroad and has no

Speaker: NA
Text: sympathy for Australia. He was born in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia and received his school educa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion here. At the outbreak of war he

Speaker: NA
Text: was in England completing his education,

Speaker: NA
Text: and in order to avoid the loss of time

Speaker: NA
Text: that would be involved in returning to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commonwealth to join up with the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Expeditionary Force, he

Speaker: NA
Text: enlisted in a British regiment, and while

Speaker: NA
Text: serving with it was gravely wounded.

Speaker: NA
Text: This bill has been introduced at

Speaker: NA
Text: an opportune, time. Australia has

Speaker: NA
Text: experienced two years of serious depres-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion, but now, because governments are

Speaker: NA
Text: restoring the country to a firm financial

Speaker: NA
Text: footing, our credit overseas is so improved

Speaker: NA
Text: that an opportunity presents itself to

Speaker: NA
Text: reduce appreciably the interest payable

Speaker: NA
Text: on the external public debt. I f Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lians are true to themselves, the New

Speaker: NA
Text: South Wales loan of £13,000,000, which

Speaker: NA
Text: will fall due in a few weeks, will probably

Speaker: NA
Text: be converted at a lower rate of interest,

Speaker: NA
Text: which will represent a saving of between

Speaker: NA
Text: £150,000 and £160,000 a year. I remind

Speaker: NA
Text: the House that large loans are not con-

Speaker: NA
Text: verted by merely publishing a notifica-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion in a newspaper. Careful negotia-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions are necessary between the financial

Speaker: NA
Text: houses and the representatives of the bor-

Speaker: NA
Text: rowing dominion. The doors of banks

Speaker: NA
Text: aud other financial institutions are

Speaker: NA
Text: strongly guarded, and do not open to

Speaker: NA
Text: I say nothing in" disparage-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of Mr Collins, who has given extra-

Speaker: NA
Text: ordinarily good service to Australia, but

Speaker: NA
Text: he has not access to those financial

Speaker: NA
Text: circles in which it is necessary to explain

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's present situation and its pros-

Speaker: NA
Text: pects. A favorable impression in those

Speaker: NA
Text: circles is essential if we are to effect a

Speaker: NA
Text: conversion upon satisfactory conditions.

Speaker: NA
Text: In those circumstances it is fortunate that

Speaker: NA
Text: the High Commissionership is at present

Speaker: NA
Text: vacant, through the expiration of Sir

Speaker: NA
Text: Granville Eyrie's term of office. This

Speaker: NA
Text: has enabled the right honorable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Flinders to proceed from Ottawa to

Speaker: NA
Text: London to carry out an operation for

Speaker: NA
Text: the ground was most care-fully

Speaker: NA
Text: prepared by the Attorney-General ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Latham) on 'his recent visit abroad.

Speaker: NA
Text: Probably in connexion with the High

Speaker: NA
Text: Comniissionership alone a saving of

Speaker: NA
Text: £2,000 a .year will be effected, and i f

Speaker: NA
Text: Resident Minister in London is able to

Speaker: NA
Text: effect the conversion of the maturing New

Speaker: NA
Text: South Wales loan upon improved con-

Speaker: NA
Text: ditions, he will in one year save 70

Speaker: NA
Text: or 80 times his own salary. The

Speaker: NA
Text: present official secretary at Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: House has not been in the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: for several years, and has no first-hand

Speaker: NA
Text: knowledge of the perils through - which

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia has recently passed. I f the

Speaker: NA
Text: conversion operations are to be successful,

Speaker: NA
Text: we must have on the spot a man who can

Speaker: NA
Text: speak with authority and first-hand know-

Speaker: NA
Text: ledge. Who is better fitted for this

Speaker: NA
Text: critical task than the right honorahle

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Flinders, who left Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: recently after taking an active aud

Speaker: NA
Text: prominent part in the public affairs of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth? Mr Collins, whom I

Speaker: NA
Text: have known and esteemed for many years,

Speaker: NA
Text: is without up-to-date knowledge of Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia's financial problems, and has not

Speaker: NA
Text: the authority and prestige which will be

Speaker: NA
Text: enjoyed by the right honorable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Flinders. Whatever may be done

Speaker: NA
Text: for us by our representative in

Speaker: NA
Text: London, our fate will be more or less in

Speaker: NA
Text: our own hands. I f we make fools of our-

Speaker: NA
Text: selves and follow false prophets who

Speaker: NA
Text: would lead us to destruction, we shall not

Speaker: NA
Text: satisfactorily convert the overseas debt

Speaker: NA
Text: and reduce our interest bill. On us alone

Speaker: NA
Text: the success of the impending transactions

Speaker: NA
Text: depends, and our mouthpiece will be the

Speaker: NA
Text: Resident Minister in London. His

Speaker: NA
Text: appointment has been described as a

Speaker: NA
Text: political plum. Having been very closely

Speaker: NA
Text: associated with him prior to his depar-

Speaker: NA
Text: ture from Australia, I am able to say

Speaker: NA
Text: definitely that he did not desire to go

Speaker: NA
Text: abroad, but went from a sense of public

Speaker: NA
Text: duty. The fact that this bill may be

Speaker: NA
Text: operative for two years does not neces-

Speaker: NA
Text: sarily mean that the right honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber for Flinders will remain abroad for

Speaker: NA
Text: that period. Probably when he has com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pleted the task which has been delegated

Speaker: NA
Text: to him, he will return to Australia, where

Speaker: NA
Text: his real interests are. But i f in order

Speaker: NA
Text: to complete his mission he should be re-

Speaker: NA
Text: quired to stay in London longer than he

Speaker: NA
Text: originally contemplated, the bill will

Speaker: NA
Text: mit him to do so for two years aud no

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr E. W. Harrison.

Speaker: NA
Text: longer. During his absence, which, I hope

Speaker: NA
Text: for Australia's sake, will not extend to

Speaker: NA
Text: two years, I shall "attend to the work of

Speaker: NA
Text: debate has reminded me of the saying

Speaker: NA
Text: The point has been made that this is

Speaker: NA
Text: a departure from established practice. I

Text: remind honorable members, however, that

Speaker: NA
Text: the subject was discussed at the Imperial

Text: Conference that was held in 1925 or 1926,

Text: when it was decided that, in the near

Text: future, each of the governments there

Text: represented should have a Besident

Text: Melbourne Ports)

Text: debate has been so considerably lowered

Text: [, and the school of thought to which I

Speaker: NA
Text: support the bill. At no time since the

Text: investors in Australia is being gradually

Text: stand the attitude of the Leader of the

Text: Th e Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: to Opposition did not say that the conver-

Text: sion should be left entirely in the hands

Text: of Mr Collins.

Text: Th e Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition said that this matter could

Text: well be left in thehands of Mr Collins,

Text: and that there was no necessity for this

Text: appointment. I have nothing but con-

Text: tempt for honorable members who have

Text: Flinders. I am entirely opposed to the

Text: London. That would hardly be a wise

Text: this position jiernianent, I should pro-

Text: test against the bill, but I do not believe

Text: that that is the desire of the Government.

Text: I hope that, in the near future, the Besi-

Speaker: NA
Text: dent Minister in London, will be able to

Text: make such financial arrangements there

Text: as will permit him to return to this

Text: country. We should not appoint a poli-

Text: tician to the position of High Commis-

Text: sioner. We must encourage trade and

Text: sideration to my suggestion, particularly

Text: the High Court.

Speaker: Mr ROSEVEAR
Text: Dalley) [9.58] -

Speaker: NA
Text: The bill, although short, has some pecu-

Speaker: NA
Text: liar features. The main argument of

Speaker: NA
Text: Ministers in support of this measure is

Speaker: NA
Text: that the appointment of a Resident

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister in London will enable us to have

Speaker: NA
Text: a better understanding of foreign policy,

Speaker: NA
Text: will give us a first-hand opportunity to

Speaker: NA
Text: convert loans that are falling due, and

Speaker: NA
Text: will probably enable us to secure a reduc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion in the rate of interest on the money

Speaker: NA
Text: that we owe abroad. I am not very much

Speaker: NA
Text: concerned about sending a Resident

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister to London to enable him to

Speaker: NA
Text: become better acquainted with foreign

Speaker: NA
Text: policy. The further we keep away

Speaker: NA
Text: from the countries which breed inter-

Speaker: NA
Text: national difficulties the better for Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia. We are quite close enough

Speaker: NA
Text: to the intrigues of Europe

Speaker: NA
Text: out sending Ministers abroad in an

Speaker: NA
Text: endeavour to participate in them. One

Speaker: NA
Text: argument used in the debate is that be-

Speaker: NA
Text: cause we have always had a High Commis-

Speaker: NA
Text: sioner, we should appoint' either a High

Speaker: NA
Text: Commissioner or a Resident Minister in

Speaker: NA
Text: London. It has also been argued by the

Speaker: NA
Text: supporters of the bill that this position

Speaker: NA
Text: has always been filled by a political dead-

Speaker: NA
Text: head. Evidently, past governments have

Speaker: NA
Text: appointed political dead-heads to this

Speaker: NA
Text: position in London in the belief that

Speaker: NA
Text: they would adequately represent Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia. Yet it is now claimed that we must

Speaker: NA
Text: send a first-class Minister abroad to take

Speaker: NA
Text: up the cudgels on behalf of the people of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. There is not the slightest

Speaker: NA
Text: doubt that the right honorable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Flinders is a capable Minister.

Speaker: NA
Text: The right honorable member for Flinders

Speaker: NA
Text: overshadows every other member of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Ministry. It was evident while he was in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia that he dominated the Cabinet

Speaker: NA
Text: and the party of which he is a member.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have not the slightest doubt that when

Speaker: NA
Text: he is abroad he will also continue to domi- from the people.

Speaker: NA
Text: nate the Government, and that the real

Speaker: NA
Text: Government of the Commonwealth will

Speaker: NA
Text: be transferred from Australia to England.

Speaker: NA
Text: The question of whether it will be diffi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cult to convert Australia's overseas in-

Text: debtedness is one on which there appears
