Text: to be a difference of opinion. Our over-

Speaker: NA
Text: seas indebtedness will be converted

Speaker: NA
Text: regardless of whether the right honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Flinders is or is not in

Speaker: NA
Text: London. The time is rapidly approach-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing when overseas bondholders will have

Speaker: NA
Text: no alternative but to agree to a conversion

Speaker: NA
Text: of their holdings at reduced rates of

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Rosevear.

Speaker: NA
Text: interest. There is nothing extraordinary

Speaker: NA
Text: associated with the conversion of loans.

Speaker: NA
Text: There have been two remarkable instances

Speaker: NA
Text: of successful conversions since the ter-

Speaker: NA
Text: mination of the war. The conversion of

Speaker: NA
Text: Great Britain's Avar debt to the United

Speaker: NA
Text: States of America was arranged Avithout

Speaker: NA
Text: the assistance of a resident minister in

Speaker: NA
Text: Washington. That conversion Avas effected

Speaker: NA
Text: not because America's regard for the

Speaker: NA
Text: mighty dollar had lessened, but be-

Speaker: NA
Text: cause America's capitalists realized

Speaker: NA
Text: that Great Britain could not continue to

Speaker: NA
Text: pay the interest that was then being

Speaker: NA
Text: charged. For precisely the same reason

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government of this country forced

Speaker: NA
Text: witha conversion loan upon local bondholders,

Speaker: NA
Text: but at the same time it alloAA'ed the over-

Speaker: NA
Text: seas -bondholders to go scot-free.

Speaker: NA
Text: Eighteen months ago Ave advocated a

Speaker: NA
Text: policy of interest reduction Avhich

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable members opposite denounced,

Speaker: NA
Text: but which this Government now

Speaker: NA
Text: supports. We realizedit Avas im-

Speaker: NA
Text: possible to continue to pay the present

Speaker: NA
Text: rate of interest on our overseas debt. Hon-

Speaker: NA
Text: orable members opposite who called it

Speaker: NA
Text: repudiation at that time now have

Speaker: NA
Text: to admit that a conversion is absolutely

Speaker: NA
Text: necessary i f Australia is to carry on. I f

Speaker: NA
Text: our suggestions had been adopted

Speaker: NA
Text: eighteen months ago the amount repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: senting the difference between, our revenue

Speaker: NA
Text: and our interest payments would

Speaker: NA
Text: have been sufficient to provide em-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployment for the hundreds of thousands

Speaker: NA
Text: of our unfortunate fellowmen who

Speaker: NA
Text: are now walking the streets in

Speaker: NA
Text: search of Avork. The policy of this

Speaker: NA
Text: Government has led it into difficulties,

Speaker: NA
Text: and i t is now endeavouring to recover its

Speaker: NA
Text: position by demanding further sacrifices

Speaker: NA
Text: The overseas bond-

Speaker: NA
Text: holders, as well as the Government,

Speaker: NA
Text: realize the actual position. The serA'ices

Speaker: NA
Text: of a High Commissioner, a Besident

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister, or any other representative in

Speaker: NA
Text: London, Avill not be needed to bring about

Speaker: NA
Text: conversion of our overseas indebtedness.

Speaker: NA
Text: Our loans will be converted; there is no

Speaker: NA
Text: doubt about that. The rates of interest

Speaker: NA
Text: may not be at the figure that the GoAern-

Speaker: NA
Text: r

Speaker: NA
Text: ment desires, but they will be governed

Speaker: NA
Text: by what the bondholders consider is the

Speaker: NA
Text: country's capacity to pay, as was the

Speaker: NA
Text: case in the conversion of Great Britain's

Speaker: NA
Text: war debt to America. The rates eventually

Speaker: NA
Text: fixed will be such that the people of Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia will have to keep their nose to the

Speaker: NA
Text: grindstone for many years to come. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Government, which is now forced to face

Speaker: NA
Text: the facts, should have done what is now

Speaker: NA
Text: proposed eighteen months ago. A reduc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion in overseas interest will be one of

Speaker: NA
Text: greatest factors in solving Australia's

Speaker: NA
Text: present difficulties. There is no need to

Speaker: NA
Text: appoint a Resident Minister in Loudon

Speaker: NA
Text: to arrange a conversion; the bondholders

Speaker: NA
Text: will be forced to convert, but it will be

Speaker: NA
Text: at a figure closely approximating the

Speaker: NA
Text: country's capacity to pay.

Speaker: Mr BERNARD CORSER
Text: Wide Bay)

Speaker: NA
Text: [10.5] -I t is not my intention to pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: long the debate by repeating the argu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments that have been advanced, by some

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable members opposite; but their

Speaker: NA
Text: bitter references to the right honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Flinders ( Mr Bruce), who,

Speaker: NA
Text: they presume, is to be appointed Besident

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister in London under this bill,

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot be allowed to pass unchal-

Speaker: NA
Text: lenged. I feel quite sure that honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: members opposite do not really believe

Speaker: NA
Text: half of what they have said concerning

Speaker: NA
Text: the right honorable member. Bather do

Speaker: NA
Text: they recognize his ability, value and in-

Speaker: NA
Text: fluence; it is their fear of him politically

Speaker: NA
Text: that has impelled them to make

Speaker: NA
Text: the statements they have made. They

Speaker: NA
Text: are anxious to harass the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of which he is a member, and to

Speaker: NA
Text: endeavour to destroy his influence and

Speaker: NA
Text: power, which have been of great value to

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. For party political reasons

Speaker: NA
Text: they have attempted to belittle the right

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member in the eyes of Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralians. The bill is to amend the High

Speaker: NA
Text: Commissioner's Act, hy making provision

Speaker: NA
Text: for the appointment in Great Britain of

Speaker: NA
Text: a Minister or a commissioner authorized

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Executive Council or the Governor-

Speaker: NA
Text: General. I t does not provide that the

Speaker: NA
Text: functions of the Besident Minister shall

Speaker: NA
Text: be confined to converting our overseas

Speaker: NA
Text: indebtedness; but i t is apparent that one

Speaker: NA
Text: of his most important duties will be the

Speaker: NA
Text: handling of a big conversion loan. I

Speaker: NA
Text: contend that there is no one in Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: more likely to secure a better hearing

Speaker: NA
Text: from Great Britain's financiers than

Speaker: NA
Text: the right honorable member for Flinders

Speaker: NA
Text: in his efforts to convert Australia's

Speaker: NA
Text: overseas debt ' of approximately

Speaker: NA
Text: €580,000,000. I t has been suggested

Speaker: NA
Text: by honorable members opposite that

Speaker: NA
Text: all the work needed could be com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pleted within one year, and that there is

Speaker: NA
Text: uo necessity to appoint a Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: two years. There is nothing in the bill

Speaker: NA
Text: tocompel the Minister appointed to

Speaker: NA
Text: the remain in London for two years i f there

Speaker: NA
Text: is not sufficient for him to do; but, in

Speaker: NA
Text: view of the highly important duties which

Speaker: NA
Text: he will have to perform, the term provided

Speaker: NA
Text: is not unreasonable. The Besident Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: is to act as High Commissioner, andinthat

Speaker: NA
Text: capacity will be expected to use his ability

Speaker: NA
Text: in increasing trade between Great Britain

Speaker: NA
Text: and Australia. London is still the finan-

Speaker: NA
Text: cial and commercial centre of the world,*

Speaker: NA
Text: notwithstanding that other countries have

Speaker: NA
Text: much larger populations. Every nation

Speaker: NA
Text: of any importance has its ambassador in

Speaker: NA
Text: London, and it is with these that our

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister will confer with a view to secur-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing new treaties and new markets for

Speaker: NA
Text: the products of our primary industries.

Speaker: NA
Text: The United States of America is

Speaker: NA
Text: represented in London by an ex-Treasurer,

Speaker: NA
Text: and it is only right that the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth should have the most able represen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tative in Great Britain for at least

Speaker: NA
Text: the term provided in ' the bill. Such a

Speaker: NA
Text: representative can negotiate treaties,

Speaker: NA
Text: extend our trade, confer with the repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sentatives of other nations, and generally

Speaker: NA
Text: act in the interests of the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: people. I am sure that whether the

Speaker: NA
Text: duties which fall upon the shoulders' of

Speaker: NA
Text: the right honorable member for Flinders

Speaker: NA
Text: relate to the conversion of our overseas

Speaker: NA
Text: indebtedness, the carrying out of services

Speaker: NA
Text: usually rendered hy the High Commis-

Speaker: NA
Text: sioner, or the negotiating of trade agree-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments, they will be discharged with dig-

Speaker: NA
Text: nity and honour to himself and with

Speaker: NA
Text: credit and benefit to Australia. A l l who

Speaker: NA
Text: are prepared to give honour where honour

Speaker: NA
Text: is due will admit that the right honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: ablemember for Flinders has, through-

Speaker: NA
Text: out his public life, endeavoured to do

Speaker: NA
Text: the best he could for Australia, and has

Speaker: NA
Text: rendered this country invaluable service.

Speaker: NA
Text: I t has been argued that the appoint-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment should not be made, because it" will

Speaker: NA
Text: mean that the electors of Flinders would

Speaker: NA
Text: be left without parliamentary representa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. I consider, however, that these

Speaker: NA
Text: electors are being honoured in the highest

Speaker: NA
Text: degree, for no other honorable member

Speaker: NA
Text: of this Parliament will be entrusted

Speaker: NA
Text: with such important aud responsible

Speaker: NA
Text: duties in relation to-our financial and

Speaker: NA
Text: commercial operations. I believe that

Speaker: NA
Text: the electors of Flinders will realize this,

Speaker: NA
Text: and will be proud that their representa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive has been honoured by appointment

Speaker: NA
Text: as the Resident Minister in London.

Speaker: Mr RIORDAN
Text: Kennedy) [10.12] -

Speaker: NA
Text: 1 am interested to learn that the right

Speaker: NA
Text: houorable member for Flinders ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bruce) has already been selected as

Speaker: NA
Text: Resident Minister in London. I thought

Speaker: NA
Text: that perhaps the right honorable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for North Sydney ( Mr Hughes), who

Speaker: NA
Text: .represented this country abroad in the

Speaker: NA
Text: critical years between 1914 and 1918,

Speaker: NA
Text: might have been chosen. I t is to be

Speaker: NA
Text: hoped that the right honorable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Flinders will live up to the high hopes

Speaker: NA
Text: that have been expressed in relation to

Speaker: NA
Text: him this evening. Australia has, in the

Speaker: NA
Text: past, borrowed heavily abroad.

Speaker: NA
Text: overseas indebtedness considerably ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: ceeds £500,000,000. I t was not neces-

Speaker: NA
Text: sary to appoint, a Resident Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: overseas to raise this money. Australia,

Speaker: NA
Text: in the past, has been able to borrow

Speaker: NA
Text: money as and when she desired it at the

Speaker: NA
Text: market rates. I n the last year or two,

Speaker: NA
Text: we have had a financial expert abroad to

Speaker: NA
Text: watch the interests of the Commonwealth.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Collins, who formerly filled the chief

Speaker: NA
Text: position in the Commonwealth Treasury,

Speaker: NA
Text: is a financial adviser to the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. I f a Resident Minister is

Speaker: NA
Text: appointed overseas, and given the duty

Speaker: NA
Text: of watching Australia's interests in

Speaker: NA
Text: regard to conversion operations and other

Speaker: NA
Text: financial transactions, it would appear

Speaker: NA
Text: to be unnecessary to keep Mr Collins

Speaker: NA
Text: there. Will the Nivison Group also

Speaker: NA
Text: continue to advise the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: Government in financial matters after the

Speaker: NA
Text: right honorable member for Flinders

Speaker: NA
Text: assumes his new duties? This right

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable gentleman, we are told, has the

Speaker: NA
Text: facts of our financial business at his

Speaker: NA
Text: finger tips, and is a financial expert

Speaker: NA
Text: of the highest calibre. I hope, there-

Speaker: NA
Text: fore, that we shall not duplicate ser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vices by allowing Mr Collins to remain

Speaker: NA
Text: in London while Mr Bruce is doing the

Speaker: NA
Text: work.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Leader of the Opposition ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: SfiiUin) said this afternoon that he was

Speaker: NA
Text: opposed to the principle of the appoint-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of a Resident Minister overseas. I t

Speaker: NA
Text: was then said that it would not be neces-

Speaker: NA
Text: sary for the right honorable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Flinders to remain in London until the

Speaker: NA
Text: last document had been signed. What

Speaker: NA
Text: loans will have to be converted this finan-

Speaker: NA
Text: cial year? We know that £13,000,000,

Speaker: NA
Text: borrowed by New South Wales will have

Speaker: NA
Text: to be converted, but this State, and other

Speaker: NA
Text: States as well, have, in the past, con-

Speaker: NA
Text: ducted their own conversion operations

Speaker: NA
Text: satisfactorily. Money, like every other

Speaker: NA
Text: commodity, is available at market rates,

Speaker: NA
Text: independent of the personality, pleasing

Speaker: NA
Text: mannerisms, or method of approach, of

Speaker: NA
Text: individuals. I n fact, a man who can

Speaker: NA
Text: tell the best story is, by common consent,

Speaker: NA
Text: the one who needs watching most care-

Speaker: NA
Text: fully, for he is the most dangerous. The

Speaker: NA
Text: straightforward honest man usually has

Speaker: NA
Text: a definite proposition to submit to his

Speaker: NA
Text: creditors. Men who have no such pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: position have need to tell a good story.

Speaker: NA
Text: Out- These are usually the people who, to use

Speaker: NA
Text: an Australian phrase, "bite you." Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia will, doubtless, be able to get what

Speaker: NA
Text: money she needs at market rates at the

Speaker: NA
Text: time the conversion has to be effected.

Speaker: NA
Text: We well remember that in 1920, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland Government found it neces-

Speaker: NA
Text: sary to convert two loans, one of

Speaker: NA
Text: butthe Commonwealth Nationalist Go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment did its utmost to render con-

Speaker: NA
Text: version operations impossible unless the

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland Government undertook to

Speaker: NA
Text: grant an extension of leases to certain

Speaker: NA
Text: pastoral lessees. Is it now proposed that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Resident Minister in London shall

Speaker: NA
Text: be in a position to barter?

Speaker: NA
Text: There would have been very little dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: cussion on this bill had the Prime Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter given us sufficient information when

Speaker: NA
Text: he introduced it. A l l he said was that

Speaker: NA
Text: the appointment was to be made for two

Speaker: NA
Text: years, but might be extended. We know

Speaker: NA
Text: very well that once a new principle is

Speaker: NA
Text: established it is very difficult to abrogate

Speaker: NA
Text: it. Whenever appointments such .as that

Speaker: NA
Text: now contemplated are made, the appoin-

Speaker: NA
Text: tee takes all possible steps to consolidate

Speaker: NA
Text: his position. Usually, he begins by

Speaker: NA
Text: building up a big staff around him.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are already indications of that in

Speaker: NA
Text: this connexion. Expenditure is also in-

Speaker: NA
Text: curred in regard to housing, and that,

Speaker: NA
Text: too, has happened in this case. At a

Speaker: NA
Text: time like this, when .the country is taxed

Speaker: NA
Text: to the utmost, aud the call is for economy,

Speaker: NA
Text: we should economize at the top. I f we

Speaker: NA
Text: cut the roots of a tree often enough,

Speaker: NA
Text: we shall destroy the tree, whereas by

Speaker: NA
Text: ping its branches we improve it. When

Speaker: NA
Text: I recall that loans amounting to over

Speaker: NA
Text: £500,000,000 have to. be converted over-

Speaker: NA
Text: seas," I am reminded that not many

Speaker: NA
Text: months ago a voluntary conversion took

Speaker: NA
Text: place in Australia. I t was, however,

Speaker: NA
Text: voluntary only in name, because those who

Speaker: NA
Text: did not convert their holdings voluntarily

Speaker: NA
Text: were compelled to do so. The Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: bondholder, as well as the man who fought

Speaker: NA
Text: in the Great War, has made his sacrifice.

Speaker: NA
Text: The London money market is improving,

Speaker: NA
Text: and to-day money is cheaper than it has

Speaker: NA
Text: been for some time. Other countries are

Speaker: NA
Text: obtaining loans at low rates of interest,

Speaker: NA
Text: and Australia, which has been a good

Speaker: NA
Text: customer of Great Britain, and has met

Speaker: NA
Text: all its obligations in the past, can look

Speaker: NA
Text: forward to renewing its loans at the ruling

Speaker: NA
Text: rate of interest. Since money lenders are

Speaker: NA
Text: not renowned for lending money for

Speaker: NA
Text: reasons of sympathy, the Resident

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister in London will have to barter

Speaker: NA
Text: with them in the same way that he and

Speaker: NA
Text: his colleagues bartered at Ottawa by

Speaker: NA
Text: giving away Australia's -industries. The

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member for Forrest ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Prowse) regretted that we did not give

Speaker: NA
Text: away more at Ottawa than we did. Our

Speaker: NA
Text: export trade in mutton has been limited

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Ottawa agreement to such an

Speaker: NA
Text: extent that Australia is in a" more un-

Speaker: NA
Text: favorable position than before. What has

Speaker: NA
Text: this country received as a result of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Ottawa Conference?

Speaker: Mr CAMERON
Text: W e do not. know yet.

Speaker: Mr RIORDAN
Text: W e ought to know,

Speaker: NA
Text: because the country will have to foot the

Speaker: NA
Text: bill.

Speaker: Mr DEIN
Text: Wha t has all this to do

Speaker: NA
Text: with the bill?

Speaker: Mr RIORDAN
Text: Al l these things have

Speaker: NA
Text: to do with the appointment of a Resident

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister overseas. The right honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Flinders, whom I recognize

Speaker: NA
Text: is an outstanding personality, although

Speaker: NA
Text: in London, will continue to dictate the

Speaker: NA
Text: policy of this country. But he in turn

Speaker: NA
Text: will have to submit to dictation by those

Speaker: NA
Text: who dictated the policy agreed to at

Speaker: NA
Text: Ottawa. The gentleman who will control

Speaker: NA
Text: our destiny did not enjoy the confidence

Speaker: NA
Text: of his party sufficiently to obtain full

Speaker: NA
Text: ministerial rank. Surely there is some

Speaker: NA
Text: inconsistency opposite. I f the right

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member for Flinders has such

Speaker: NA
Text: lop- outstanding ability, why did the United

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia party first place him in a

Speaker: NA
Text: subordinate position, and then, at the first

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity, shanghai him overseas? I

Speaker: NA
Text: was pleased to hear the honorable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Bendigo ( Mr E. F. Harrison) say

Speaker: NA
Text: that he would look after the electors in

Speaker: NA
Text: the Flinders electorate during the absence

Speaker: NA
Text: of their representative. In order to serve

Speaker: NA
Text: the interests of Flinders, the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member is prepared to neglect the

Speaker: NA
Text: interests of Bendigo. Were he really con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cerned about the best interests of the

Speaker: NA
Text: people whom he represents, he would fight

Speaker: NA
Text: for the continuation of the gold bounty,

Speaker: NA
Text: with a view to reviving the gold-mining

Speaker: NA
Text: industry in his district. I n my opinion,

Speaker: NA
Text: the principle of government from London

Speaker: NA
Text: ia bad, but i f it is necessary to have a

Speaker: NA
Text: Resident Minister in Britain, why not

Speaker: NA
Text: have one also iu Japan, and China, and,

Speaker: NA
Text: indeed, in every country with which we

Speaker: NA
Text: do business? What has beeu said to-day

Speaker: NA
Text: about the right honorable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Flinders has been said in the past of Sir

Speaker: NA
Text: Granville Ryrie, Mr Andrew Fisher, Sir

Speaker: NA
Text: Joseph Cook, Mr Devereux, and

Speaker: NA
Text: others. I am not deceived by these words

Speaker: NA
Text: of praise. Australia .should be represented

Speaker: NA
Text: in Britain, not by politicians, but by men

Speaker: NA
Text: trained in the commercial world. Half

Speaker: NA
Text: a dozen commercial travellers in London

Speaker: NA
Text: would do more good for Australia than

Speaker: NA
Text: could be achieved hy the same number

Speaker: NA
Text: of politicians, who would only pile up

Speaker: NA
Text: expenses.

Speaker: Mr BAKER
Text: Oxley) [10.29] - I asso-

Speaker: NA
Text: ciate myself with those who have

Speaker: NA
Text: expressed their opposition to this bill!

Speaker: NA
Text: The House has been given scanty informa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion as to the purpose of the measure.

Speaker: NA
Text: I f honorable members on this side have

Speaker: NA
Text: criticized the qualifications of the gentle-

Speaker: NA
Text: man whom it is suggested shall carry out

Speaker: NA
Text: the duties of High Commissioner, the

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibility lies with the Government,

Speaker: NA
Text: which appears to be basing its case upon

Speaker: NA
Text: the abilities of the suggested appointee.

Speaker: NA
Text: While Prime Minister of Australia he

Speaker: NA
Text: showed remarkable ability in concealing

Speaker: NA
Text: the fact that he possessed any. The chief

Speaker: NA
Text: memory that we have of him is that he

Speaker: NA
Text: took over from the Hughes Government

Speaker: NA
Text: a surplus in the vicinity of £7,000,000

Speaker: NA
Text: and bequeathed to his successor i n office

Speaker: NA
Text: a deficit of £6,500,000.

Speaker: NA
Text: Another reason which probably actuates

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government in this appointment is

Speaker: NA
Text: that the position of the Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: is similar to that of the individual men-

Speaker: NA
Text: tioned i n Pope's poem, who, like the

Speaker: NA
Text: Turk, could " bear no brother near the

Speaker: NA
Text: throne". I n this instance, i t also suits

Speaker: NA
Text: the right honorable member f o r Flinders.

Speaker: NA
Text: On the one hand, i t removes a dangerous

Speaker: NA
Text: rival, and on the other i t enables the

Speaker: NA
Text: person concerned to pay a good deal of

Speaker: NA
Text: attention to his private business over-

Speaker: NA
Text: seas.

Speaker: Mr LANE
Text: W h y cannot the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member be fair?

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr BAKER . ' - I am f a i r . I shall

Speaker: NA
Text: quote f r o m a journal which cannot be

Speaker: NA
Text: accused of being unsympathetically dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: posed towards the Nationalist member f o r

Speaker: NA
Text: Flinders or the Nationalist party. M y

Speaker: NA
Text: reading is f r o m the Melbourne Argus of

Speaker: NA
Text: the 23rd December, 1931, and is as f o l -

Speaker: NA
Text: lows :-

Speaker: NA
Text: I t is possible tliat Mr Bruce, notwith-

Speaker: NA
Text: standing his long experience both as Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister and Treasurer and his prestige over-

Speaker: NA
Text: seas, will not be a member of the Ministry at

Speaker: NA
Text: all. Mr Bruce, who is now returning to Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia from a trip to England, has his hands

Speaker: NA
Text: filled with the affairs of the business of

Speaker: NA
Text: Paterson, Laing and Bruce, which he has

Speaker: NA
Text: again taken up since his temporary retirement

Speaker: NA
Text: from politics. I t is questionable whether he

Speaker: NA
Text: will be able to spare the time to attend to the

Speaker: NA
Text: administration of an important public depart-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment.

Speaker: NA
Text: That appeared at a time when there was

Speaker: NA
Text: considerable discussion regarding the pos-

Speaker: NA
Text: sible personnel of the new federal

Text: This act shall continue in operation for a

Text: West Sydney) [10.45].

Speaker: NA
Text: - I move the following amendment:-

Speaker: NA
Text: That the words " two years" be omitted

Speaker: NA
Text: with a view to insert in lieu thereof the words

Speaker: NA
Text: " six months ".

Speaker: NA
Text: The supporters of this bill have argued

Speaker: NA
Text: that the main purpose of appointing a

Speaker: NA
Text: Resident Minister in London is to effect

Speaker: NA
Text: the conversion of our overseas debt. I f

Speaker: NA
Text: we accept that argument, we take leave to

Speaker: NA
Text: point out that, unless this conversion is

Speaker: NA
Text: carried through within six months, Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia's finances w i l l be in a very sorry

Speaker: NA
Text: plight. The taxpayers cannot continue

Speaker: NA
Text: to meet the present exorbitant rate of

Speaker: NA
Text: 42 interest. We on this side of the House

Speaker: NA
Text: have urged for the last eighteen months

Speaker: NA
Text: or two years the need forundertaking

Speaker: NA
Text: this conversion, and the longer i t is

Speaker: NA
Text: delayed the more serious the problem will

Speaker: NA
Text: AYES. become. A further reason for proposing

Speaker: NA
Text: to reduce'the duration of the act is to

Speaker: NA
Text: minimize the expense incidental to the

Speaker: NA
Text: keeping of a Resident Minister i n London.

Speaker: NA
Text: By moving this amendment I hope to

Speaker: NA
Text: impress upon honorable members, and

Speaker: NA
Text: upon the people generally, the urgency

Speaker: NA
Text: of converting our overseas debt.

Text: Dalley) [10.48] -

Speaker: NA
Text: [ support the amendment. I f the object

Text: of this mission is to be achieved at all-

Speaker: NA
Text: torium

Text: Kooyong-Attorney -

Speaker: NA
Text: General) [11.9] --Th e distinction ia

Speaker: NA
Text: between what are described in the Con-

Speaker: NA
Text: stitution as Ministers of State administer-

Speaker: NA
Text: Section 7 of the High Commissioner Act

Speaker: NA
Text: reads-

Speaker: NA
Text: A person appointed to be the High Commis-

Speaker: NA
Text: sioner shall not during his tenure of office be

Speaker: NA
Text: or act as director or agent of or hold any

Speaker: NA
Text: office in any company or syndicate, whether

Speaker: NA
Text: incorporated or unincorporated, or hold any

Speaker: NA
Text: other employment, or engage in any business

Speaker: NA
Text: whether within or without the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth.

Speaker: NA
Text: We all know that the right honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Flinders has interests in pri-

Speaker: NA
Text: vate business houses, notably that of

Speaker: NA
Text: Notts. Paterson, Laing and Bruce Limited.

Speaker: NA
Text: Would not the performance by him of the

Speaker: NA
Text: duties of High Commissioner be a con-

Speaker: NA
Text: travention of the aet?

Text: Kooyong-Attorney -

Speaker: NA
Text: General) [11.12] -Ther e is no inconsis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tency between this amending bill and the

Speaker: NA
Text: High Commissioner Act. .Section 7, to

Speaker: NA
Text: which the honorable member for Hunter

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr James) has just directed attention,

Speaker: NA
Text: refers to a person who is appointed as

Speaker: NA
Text: High Commissioner under the terms of

Speaker: NA
Text: that act for the period mentioned in sec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion 3. This bill does not appoint a

Speaker: NA
Text: person to that office at all. A l l that it

Speaker: NA
Text: does is to empower a Minister or member

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Executive Council to perform the

Speaker: NA
Text: functions and duties of the High Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: missioner. When a Minister is being

Speaker: NA
Text: appointed for a temporary period, there

Speaker: NA
Text: are not thought to be the same reasons

Speaker: NA
Text: to apply the provisions of section 7 to

Speaker: NA
Text: such appointment.

Text: Nevertheless , this bill

Speaker: NA
Text: is a violation of the spirit of section 7.

Speaker: Mr LATHAM
Text: I t is open to Parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment tolegislate that every mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber of i t should surrender all commercial,

Speaker: NA
Text: industrial and financial interests; that,

Speaker: NA
Text: in fact, he should be occupied with no

Speaker: NA
Text: other duties. I t could so provide f o r

Speaker: NA
Text: Ministers and, i f it thought proper, any

Speaker: NA
Text: person appointed under any act; but I

Speaker: NA
Text: am glad to say that up to the present

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament has taken the more generous

Speaker: NA
Text: and the wiser Anew that Ministers and

Speaker: NA
Text: members should not divorce themselves

Speaker: NA
Text: from the general activities of the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munity.

Speaker: Mr BEASLEY
Text: West Sydney) [11.14].

Speaker: NA
Text: - I t is clear, from the remarks of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Attorney-General ( Mr Latham) that the

Speaker: NA
Text: right honorable member for Flinders

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Bruce) would not be eligible for

Speaker: NA
Text: appointment as High Commissioner, and

Speaker: NA
Text: that any such appointment would be in

Speaker: NA
Text: contravention of section 7 of the High

Speaker: NA
Text: Commissioner Act.

Speaker: Mr LATHAM
Text: I f i t fell within section

Speaker: NA
Text: 7, yes.

Speaker: Mr BEASLEY
Text: Therefore , the point

Speaker: NA
Text: made by the honorable member for Oxley

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Baker) was an important one.

Speaker: Mr LATHAM
Text: I t is perfectly obvious

Speaker: NA
Text: that a distinction is being drawn be-

Speaker: NA
Text: tween a Minister and another person

Speaker: NA
Text: appointed as High Commissioner.

Speaker: Mr BEASLEY
Text: On e aspect which

Speaker: NA
Text: we should bear in mind is that, while the

Speaker: NA
Text: right honorable member for Flinders has

Speaker: NA
Text: not actually been appointed High Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: missioner, he will discharge all the func-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions and duties of that office.

Speaker: Mr SCULLIN
Text: Unde r a different title.

Speaker: Mr BEASLEY
Text: Tha t being so, the

Speaker: NA
Text: explanation offered by the Attorney-

Speaker: NA
Text: General is very thin.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr .SCULLIN -Th e bill certainly

Speaker: NA
Text: violates the spirit of the original act.

Speaker: Mr BEASLEY
Text: Ther e is no doubt

Speaker: NA
Text: about that, and I am certain that the

Speaker: NA
Text: people generally will appreciate the point

Speaker: NA
Text: that has been raised by the - honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Oxley.

Speaker: Mr HOLLOWAY
Text: Melbourne Ports)

Speaker: NA
Text: [11.15],- I should like to know from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister in charge of the bill ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Parkhill) i f it has been specially drafted

Speaker: NA
Text: to overcome the difficulty which has just

Speaker: NA
Text: been mentioned, namely, that the right

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member for Flinders or any

Speaker: NA
Text: other honorable member was ineligible for

Speaker: NA
Text: appointment to the position of High

Speaker: NA
Text: Commissioner under the principal act?

Speaker: Mr ARCHDALE PARKHILL
Text: War-

Speaker: NA
Text: ringah-Ministe r for the Interior)

Speaker: NA
Text: [11.16] -Th e bill was not drafted for

Speaker: NA
Text: the purpose suggested by the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Melbourne Ports ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Holloway). Nor is it true to say that the

Speaker: NA
Text: measure is merely a. subterfuge to enable

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government to invest the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: who happens to be in London with autho-

Speaker: NA
Text: rity to discharge duties ordinarily per-

Speaker: NA
Text: formed by the High Commissioner. I t

Speaker: NA
Text: would be anomalous for a Minister to be

Speaker: NA
Text: at Australia House and have no authority

Speaker: NA
Text: whatever.

Speaker: Mr SCULLIN
Text: Th e Minister surely

Speaker: NA
Text: does not seriously suggest that a Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: would have no authority over public ser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vants in Australia House!

Speaker: Mr ARCHDALE PARKHILL
Text: I do.

Speaker: NA
Text: Some of our officials there are of very

Speaker: NA
Text: high standing, and some Ministers are

Speaker: NA
Text: still modest enough to be disinclined to

Speaker: NA
Text: exert control without specific authority

Speaker: NA
Text: from Parliament. The bill merely pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vides that the Minister who happens to

Speaker: NA
Text: be in London for the time being shall exer-

Speaker: NA
Text: cise the necessary authority of and dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: charge the duties ordinarily performed by

Speaker: NA
Text: the High Commissioner. The Leader of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition ( Mr Scullin) has ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: mitted that i t is essential for some

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister to be there, although he affects

Speaker: NA
Text: to believe that later everything, can be left

Speaker: NA
Text: to Mr Collins, the Official Secretary.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government takes the view that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister in London should be authorized

Speaker: NA
Text: to do all that it is proposed to do.

Speaker: Mr BAKER
Text: Oxley) [11.17] - I f this

Speaker: NA
Text: bill is hot a subterfuge, why does not

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government give the Besident

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister the title of High Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: missioner ? Obviously, the reason is that

Speaker: NA
Text: it would be a contravention of section 7 of

Speaker: NA
Text: the High Commissioner Act. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Attorney-General ( Mr Latham) said

Speaker: NA
Text: just now that, as the Besident Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: would be in London for only a short

Speaker: NA
Text: period, it was not necessary to do so; but

Speaker: NA
Text: when he was speaking to the second

Speaker: NA
Text: reading of the bill, ha expressed tbe

Speaker: NA
Text: opinion that the appointment 'should be

Speaker: NA
Text: t'or a longer period than two years; that,

Speaker: NA
Text: in fact, i t should be approved as a prin-

Speaker: NA
Text: ciple. This bill is a violation of the spirit Dein, A. K.

Speaker: NA
Text: of the act of 1909, which i t seeks to

Speaker: NA
Text: amend. The Attorney-General added

Speaker: NA
Text: chat, i f the act were so construed as to

Speaker: NA
Text: render the right honorable member f o r

Speaker: NA
Text: flinders ineligible, i t might also be sug-

Speaker: NA
Text: gested that i t should apply to.al l mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers of Parliament. As a matter of fact,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Constitution does restrict members of

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament by preventing them from

Speaker: NA
Text: holding an office of profit under the

Speaker: NA
Text: Crown, - and provides, further, that no

Speaker: NA
Text: member shall be absent f r o m a session

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Parliament f o r more than

Speaker: NA
Text: two months without leave. Certainly i t

Speaker: NA
Text: was never contemplated that legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: would have to be introduced to provide

Speaker: NA
Text: for such a position as has now arisen.

Speaker: Mr WARD
Text: East Sydney) [11.22] -

Speaker: NA
Text: Evidently those who framed the original

Speaker: NA
Text: act thought that a definite restriction

Speaker: NA
Text: should be imposed upon the business

Speaker: NA
Text: activities of any person occupying the

Speaker: NA
Text: position ofHigh Commissioner.

Speaker: NA
Text: mere transfer of the duties of H i g h

Speaker: NA
Text: Commissioner to a Besident Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: does not alter the principle laid down

Speaker: NA
Text: in section 7 or reduce the opportunities of

Speaker: NA
Text: the occupant of the office to further the

Speaker: NA
Text: interests of any fir m with which he is

Speaker: NA
Text: itonnected. The suggestion earlier i n the

Speaker: NA
Text: debate, that some personal advantage

Speaker: NA
Text: might accrue to a representative of

Speaker: NA
Text: m important firm holding this office,

Speaker: NA
Text: was ridiculed. I t is apparent, how-

Speaker: NA
Text: ever, that great care was taken i n

Speaker: NA
Text: the framing of this clause, because the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government realized that the principle

Speaker: NA
Text: contained i n section 7 must be violated

Speaker: NA
Text: if the right honorable member f o r

Speaker: NA
Text: Flinders ( Mr Bruce) were to occupy the

Speaker: NA
Text: office of High Commissioner, while re-

Speaker: NA
Text: taining his connexion with a private

Speaker: NA
Text: .business firm. For that reason I shall

Speaker: NA
Text: rote against the clause.
